revision.text:
{{advert|date=June 2018}} {{undisclosed paid|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox website | name = LookSmart | logo = LookSmart logo.png | foundation = {{start date and age|1995}}
(as Homebase)
{{start date and age|1998}}
(as LookSmart) | location = [[San Francisco]] | founder = [[Evan Thornley]]
Tracy Ellery | homepage = {{URL|http://www.looksmart.com/}} | alexa = 68,929 (2 June 2018){{cite web | url=http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/looksmart.com | title=Alexa Internet: Looksmart.com | publisher=[[Alexa Internet]]}} }} '''LookSmart''' is a [[search advertising]] company. It provides search, powered by [[Google Search]], and [[pay-per-click]] and contextual advertising services. LookSmart also licenses and manages search ad networks as [[white-label product]]s. It abides by the click measurement guidelines of the [[Interactive Advertising Bureau]].{{cite web | url=https://www.iab.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/click-measurement-guidelines2009.pdf | title=Interactive Advertising Bureau Click Measurement Guidelines Version 1.0—Final Release | publisher=[[Interactive Advertising Bureau]] | date=May 12, 2009 }} ==History== The company was founded as Homebase in late 1995 in [[Melbourne]], Australia by husband and wife [[Evan Thornley]] and Tracy Ellery, executives of [[McKinsey & Company]].{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OciNwH5k4O0C&pg=PA430 | title=Enterprise and Venture Capital: A Business Builders' and Investors' Handbook | first=Christopher | last=Golis | publisher=ReadHowYouWant.com | year=2010}} [[Reader's Digest]] invested $5 million in the company for an 80% stake. In November 1996, the company launched its Looksmart service.{{cite news | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ygkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA54 | title=Newsline | work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | date=November 9, 1996}} After leadership changes at Reader's Digest, the company was sold back to the founders as well as Martin Hosking, with Reader's Digest providing a $1.5 million loan and retaining a 10% equity stake. In May 1998, the company raised $2.3 million from Amwin and $6.0 million from [[Cox Media Group]] and [[Macquarie Group]] and was valued at $23.2 million. The company also relocated to [[San Francisco]]. In 1998, the company reached an agreement to provide directory and listing services for [[Microsoft]]. The deal provided the company with $30 million upfront and guaranteed payments of $5 million per year for 5 years. By 1999, the company had 500 employees. In April 1999, the company raised $59.6 million based on a post-money valuation of $430 million. On August 20, 1999, during the [[dot-com bubble]], the company became a [[public company]] via an [[initial public offering]], raising $92 million based on a $1 billion valuation for the company.{{cite web | url=https://www.nasdaq.com/markets/ipos/company/looksmart-ltd-9351-5507 | title=LOOKSMART LTD (LOOK) IPO | publisher=[[NASDAQ]]}} By October 1999, the stock price would reach $30 per share, giving the company a [[market capitalization]] of $2.5 billion.{{cite news | url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/thom-calandras-stockwatch-looksmart-shares-poised-for-something-but-what | title=LookSmart shares poised for something, but what? | work=[[Marketwatch]] | date=October 14, 1999}} The founders' 15% stake was worth $375 million.{{cite news | url=https://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/01/21/1074360833933.html | title=LookSmart not looking smart | first=James | last=Chessell | work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | date=January 22, 2004}} In March 2000, the stock price peaked at over $70 per share.{{cite news | url=https://www.forbes.com/2000/10/04/1004looksmart.html | title=LookSmart Gets Wise To Value Of Volunteers | work=[[Forbes]] | date=October 4, 2000}} In September 2000, the company acquired [[Zeal (web)|Zeal]] for $20 million. The founders only sold around 5% of their stock before the dot-com bubble collapsed.{{cite news | url=https://www.crikey.com.au/2009/01/14/thornley-2-looksmart-share-sell-off-remains-unexplained/ | title=Thornley 2: LookSmart share sell-off remains unexplained | first=Adam | last=Schwab | work=[[Crikey]] | date=January 14, 2009}}{{subscription required}} As a result of the dot-com bubble bursting in late 2000, the company fired 172 employees or 31% of its staff in January 2001 to cut costs.{{cite news | url=https://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/stories/2001/01/08/daily59.html | title=Layoffs for Looksmart | work=[[American City Business Journals]] | date=January 12, 2001}} In March 2002, the company acquired [[WiseNut]] for $9.25 million in stock.{{cite news | url=https://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/stories/2002/03/11/daily15.html | title=LookSmart acquires WiseNut | work=[[American City Business Journals]] | date=March 12, 2002}} In July 2002, Thornley resigned as CEO but stayed on as chairman. Three of the seven members of the [[board of directors]] resigned. By then the stock was trading at 16 cents per share.{{cite news | url=https://www.theage.com.au/articles/2002/06/29/1023864671788.html | title=Thornley tips LookSmart profits after boardroom showdown | first1=Jenny | last1=Sinclair | first2=Kim | last2=Zetter | work=[[The Age]] | date=July 2, 2002}} The company announced in August 2003 that Microsoft, which accounted for 70% of the company's revenues, was testing its own search tools and the stock dropped 20% in a day.{{cite news | url=https://www.zdnet.com/article/looksmarts-microsoft-deal-looks-rocky/ | title=LookSmart's Microsoft deal looks rocky | first=Matt | last=Hines | work=[[ZDNet]] | date=August 18, 2003}} On October 7, 2003, Microsoft announced that it would not renew its agreement with Looksmart and the company's stock price plunged 52% in a day.{{cite news | url=https://www.forbes.com/free_forbes/2005/1031/182.html | title=Your Big Best Friend--Or Not | first=Kurt | last=Badenhausen | work=[[Forbes]] | date=October 31, 2005}}{{cite news | url=https://www.bizjournals.com/sacramento/stories/2003/10/06/daily17.html | title=Deal with Microsoft dies and LookSmart's stock plummets | work=[[American City Business Journals]] | date=October 7, 2003}} In September 2003, the company settled a lawsuit filed in 2002 by customers after the company converted thousands of websites that originally had paid a onetime submission fee into a cost-per-click payment model. In May 2004, Thornley resigned as chairman and was replaced by Teresa Dial. Under Dial's leadership, Looksmart acquired [[Furl]] in September 2004.{{cite news | url=https://techcrunch.com/2009/03/09/diigo-buys-web-page-clipping-service-furl-away-from-looksmart/ | title=Diigo Buys Web Page Clipping Service Furl Away From Looksmart | work=[[TechCrunch]] | date=March 9, 2009 }} Also during 2004, the company sold its Australian operations. In October 2004, David Hills was appointed CEO.{{cite press release | url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20070801006108/en/LookSmart-Announces-Executive-Management-Change | title=LookSmart Announces Executive Management Change | publisher=[[Business Wire]] | date=August 1, 2007}} John Simonelli, the [[CFO]] of the company, would resign in June 2007.{{cite news | url=https://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/stories/2007/06/04/daily47.html | title=LookSmart's CFO to step down | work=[[American City Business Journals]] | date=June 7, 2007}} By July 2007, the company sold [[Grub (search engine)|Grub]] to [[Wikia]]{{cite news | url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2007/07/27/wikia_grub_looksmart/ | title=Wikia snatches open search software from LookSmart | first=Ashlee | last=Vance | work=[[The Register]] | date=July 27, 2007}} for $50,000.{{cite web | url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1077866/000119312507242517/d10q.htm | title=LOOKSMART, LTD. 2007 Form 10-K Annual Report | publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]}} Further developments in 2007 included Hills resigning as CEO in August. and the company selling Zeal in October 2007 for $50,000. In March 2009, the company sold Furl to [[Diigo]]. Michael Onghai was named CEO in February 2013. In August 2013, the company acquired Syncapse.{{cite press release | url=https://globenewswire.com/news-release/2013/08/15/567281/10045225/en/LookSmart-to-Acquire-the-Assets-of-Syncapse.html | title=LookSmart to Acquire the Assets of Syncapse | publisher=[[Globe Newswire]] | date=August 15, 2013}} In October 2015, the company transferred all of its assets to a new entity and the former entity was merged with Pyxis Tankers so that Pyxis could become a [[public company]].{{cite press release | url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/pyxis-tankers-inc-completes-merger-with-looksmart-ltd-and-expects-to-commence-trading-on-the-nasdaq-capital-market-today-538019201.html | title=Pyxis Tankers Inc. Completes Merger with LookSmart, Ltd. and Expects to Commence Trading on the NASDAQ Capital Market Today | publisher=[[PR Newswire]] | date=October 28, 2015}} In March 2017, the company de-registered its common stock and suspended its public reporting obligations.{{cite press release | url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/looksmart-group-effects-1-for-100-reverse-stock-split-to-deregister-applies-to-become-otc-pink-currentalternative-reporting-300429177.html | title=LookSmart Group Effects 1 For 100 Reverse Stock Split, To Deregister, Applies To Become OTC Pink Current/Alternative Reporting | publisher=[[PR Newswire]] | date=March 24, 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist|1}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Looksmart}} [[Category:Companies based in San Francisco]] [[Category:Companies established in 1995]] [[Category:Dot-com bubble]] [[Category:Media companies of the United States]] [[Category:Web directories]]

page.title: Magajane v Chairperson, North West Gambling Board

revision.text:
In '''''Miller v Janks''''', an important case in [[South African insolvency law]], the court held that an insolvent possesses an estate capable of being sequestrated even though, at the time of sequestration, his estate consists only of liabilities.
== Facts == Miller had acquired an estate by means of his occupation as a professional gambler. His assets had subsequently disappeared under suspicious circumstances, leaving only liabilities. Miller’s wife possessed fixed property, which she had received while Miller was pursuing his occupation.
In an application by Janks to sequestrate Miller’s estate, Miller contended that sequestration was not competent because he had no assets and, therefore, no estate.
== Law == In ''Ex parte Collins'', the judge had held that an estate consists both of assets and of liabilities. If there were no assets but only liabilities, there could be no estate (and ''vice versa''). Were this proposition correct, no order of compulsory sequestration could be granted where the debtor, immediately prior to the application for sequestration, had got rid of all his assets by a series of depositions.
== Judgment == The court granted an order sequestrating Miller’s estate. It rejected Miller’s argument that, because he no longer had any assets, he had ceased to have an estate and that therefore sequestration was not possible.
== See also == * [[South African insolvency law]]
== References == * ''Miller v Janks'' 1944 TPD 127.
== Notes == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:1944 in South African law]] [[Category:1944 in case law]] [[Category:South African insolvency case law]] [[Category:Transvaal Provincial Division cases]]
{{SouthAfrica-case-law-stub}}

{{multiple issues|{{notability|date=November 2018}}}} {{Infobox currency | image_1 = Namecoin logo.svg | image_2 = | image_width_1 = 110 | image_width_2 = 170 | image_title_1 = | image_title_2 = | iso_code = | iso_number = |subunit_name_1 = mNMC (Milli Namecoin) | symbol = NMC | frequently_used_coins = |subunit_ratio_1 = 0.001 |subunit_ratio_2 = 0.000001 |subunit_ratio_3 = 0.00000001 |subunit_name_2 = µNMC (Micro Namecoin) |subunit_name_3 = Swartz | date_of_introduction = 18 April 2011 | inflation_title = [[Monetary inflation|Production]] | inflation_source_date = [http://bitinfocharts.com/namecoin Namecoin Statistics] |inflation_method = Automatic adjusted difficulty every two weeks. | Fraction = 10''8'' units per NMC }} '''Namecoin''' ([[currency symbol|Symbol]]: '''ℕ''' or '''NMC''') is a [[cryptocurrency]] that implements the [[top level domain]] [[.bit]], which is independent of [[ICANN]]. Namecoin was mentioned by [[ICANN]] in a public draft report as the most well-known example of distributing control and privacy in [[DNS]].{{cite news|url=https://www.icann.org/en/system/files/files/report-21feb14-en.pdf|title=The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers Identifier Technology Innovation – Draft Report|date=2014-02-21|work=ICANN}} Other proposed use cases include [[notary]]/[[timestamp]] systems.{{cite news | url=http://news.techworld.com/security/3449015/could-the-bitcoin-network-be-used-as-an-ultrasecure-notary-service/ | title=Could the Bitcoin network be used as an ultrasecure notary service? | work=Techworld | first=Jeremy | last=Kirk | date=2013-05-24 }} A 2015 study found that of the 120,000 domain names registered on Namecoin, only 28 were in use.Kalodner, H. A., Carlsten, M., Ellenbogen, P., Bonneau, J., & Narayanan, A. (2015, June). [http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.698.4605&rep=rep1&type=pdf "An Empirical Study of Namecoin and Lessons for Decentralized Namespace Design"]. In ''WEIS''. Namecoin is created by "merged mining," a process which reuses partial solutions to [[Proof-of-work system|proof-of-work]] problems from a parent cryptocurrency as valid proofs-of-work for a child cryptocurrency.Alexei Zamyatin, 24 august 2017. Merged Mining: Analysis of Effects and Implications http://repositum.tuwien.ac.at/obvutwhs/download/pdf/2315652?originalFilename=true == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == {{Commons category|Namecoin}} * {{Official website|https://www.namecoin.org/}} {{Cryptocurrencies|state=expanded}} {{Portal bar|Anarchism|Cryptography|Economics|Free software|Internet|Numismatics}} [[Category:Alternative Internet DNS services]] [[Category:Cryptocurrencies]] [[Category:Domain name system]] [[Category:Currency introduced in 2011]]

[[File:Nasothek-2.jpg|thumb|Nasothek displaying marble body parts once used to "repair" antique statuary.]]A '''nasothek''' (from the Latin ''{{lang|la|nasus}}'' "nose" and Greek {{lang|grc|θήκη}} "container") is a collection of sculpted noses.
==Carlsberg display of restoration noses== The [[Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek]] museum in Copenhagen has a nasothek collection that displays restored noses that were removed from portrait busts and statues after changes in the museum's [[art restoration]] policies.<ref name=Huizing>{{cite book|title=Klinik der menschlichen Sinne|year=2008|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-3-211-76632-3|pages=66|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XaOg_nkDQR0C|author=E.H. Huizing|chapter=The Nose and Beyond—No Nose|accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref><ref name=restor>{{cite book|title=History of restoration of ancient stone sculptures|year=2003|publisher=Getty Publications|isbn=978-0-89236-723-8|pages=207–224|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZNAVlaA6FuUC|author=Mette Moltesen|editor=Janet Burnett Grossman|chapter=Fifty years of restoration work in the Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek|display-editors=etal}}</ref> The noses, some made of marble and others of plaster, were all originally exhibited on the Greek and Roman statues in the glyptotek itself.<ref>Sign in Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek under its nasothek display</ref>
[[File:Nasothek.JPG|thumb|left|Detail: A closer look at the Copenhagen Nasothek display shows wide variety in surface textures and style.]]The [[Marble#Sculpture|white marble]] favored by Classical sculptors is easily broken, and many antique statues have been damaged since their creation by accidents, [[iconoclasm]], or vandalism. During the 19th century, it was common practice for museums to exhibit such marble sculptures in a "restored" state, with damaged parts repaired or reconstructed to make the statue look as much as possible as it did when it was first created. The noses of antique statues are especially likely to be damaged or missing, so many Greek or Roman statues acquired new noses during this era. Modern exhibition practice may differ from museum to museum. The minimalist approach prescribes removing such 19th-century additions in the interest of authenticity, as has been done in Copenhagen.<ref name=Getty>{{cite web|title=Getty Exhibition Spotlights Practices In Antiquities Conservation|url=http://www.getty.edu/news/press/center/hope_hygieia_release_040208.html|publisher=J. Paul Getty Museum|accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref>
The Ny Carlsberg museum, which has an extensive collection of Greek and Roman marble statues, participated both in 19th-century restoration and in 20th-century "de-restoration." As a result, many Roman portrait heads are now noseless again, with their restored noses removed to the museum's nasothek.<ref name=restor/>
The museum display explains its contents in both Danish and English. The English description says, "The word ''nasothek'' means a collection of noses, in analogy with ''{{linktext|discotheque}}'', a collection of records."<ref name=restor/> The Danish explanation compares "nasotek" (Danish equivalent of "nasothek") to "{{linktext|bibliotek}}", a collection of books.<ref name=restor/>
==Lund display of plaster casts of noses== [[File:Nya NasoteketCropped.jpg|180px|thumb|right|Display of plaster casts of noses at [[Lund University]]]] The ''Nasoteket'' at [[Lund University]] in Sweden consists of a display of more than 100 plaster casts of noses, including a cast of the silver nose of [[Tycho Brahe]].<ref name=obscura>{{cite web|title=The Nose Academy|url=http://atlasobscura.com/place/nose-academy|publisher=Atlas Obscura|accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.flickr.com/photos/jo_duffy/4734337798/ Photograph of display information about Copenhagen's collection of noses provided by the Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek ] * [http://jabberwokabout.blogspot.com/2009/09/lund-sweden-friday-21-august-2009.html Traveler describes a visit to Lund's collection of noses]
[[Category:Museology]] [[Category:Nose]] [[Category:Sculpture collections]]

page.title: National Centre for Australian Children's Literature

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=December 2011}}
The '''National Centre for Australian Children's Literature''', formerly known as the Lu Rees Archives, is a not-for-profit study and research centre housed at the [[University of Canberra Library]].<ref>[https://www.canberra.edu.au/national-centre-for-australian-childrens-literature National Centre for Australian Children's Literature] [[University of Canberra]]</ref> The Centre "strives to enhance the appreciation of [[Australian literature#Children's literature|Australian children's literature]] by collecting, preserving and making available wide-ranging resources",<ref>The Strategic Plan Sub-Committee [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/attachments/pdf/StratPlan2011-15Final.pdf "Lu Rees Archives of Australian Children's Literature Strategic Plan 2011-2015"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406003352/http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/attachments/pdf/StratPlan2011-15Final.pdf |date=6 April 2012 }}, page 5. Retrieved 12 July 2011. "Mission: We strive to enhance the appreciation of Australian children's literature by collecting, preserving and making available wide-ranging resources."</ref> including "both the literature and the historical and cultural context in which it was created".<ref>The Strategic Plan Sub-Committee [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/attachments/pdf/StratPlan2011-15Final.pdf "Lu Rees Archives of Australian Children's Literature Strategic Plan 2011-2015"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406003352/http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/attachments/pdf/StratPlan2011-15Final.pdf |date=6 April 2012 }}, page 5. Retrieved 12 July 2011. "Aim: We aim to provide resources for the study and research of Australian children's authors and illustrators, including both the literature and the historical and cultural context in which it was created."</ref>
==History== In 1974 [[Lu Rees]], then President of the ACT Branch of [[Children's Book Council of Australia|The Children's Book Council of Australia]], proposed to the other branches, that the ACT Branch would begin a collection of biographical files on Australian children's authors and illustrators and a collection of their works. Lu Rees offered her personal collection of several hundred works "as a first step." <ref>Rees, Lu (1981). "In the beginning (Reprinted from issue 1, 1981)." Notes, Books and Authors, 27th issue, 2005, page 3. "As a first step in this I offered to hand over my personal collection of a few hundred books as soon as there was a place to put them – this would be something to build on."</ref> The collection was maintained in the home of a member of [[Children's Book Council of Australia|The Children's Book Council of Australia]], and developed with donations mainly from Children's Book Council of Australia members. In 1979, in response to the [[International Year of the Child]], Lu Rees initiated a plan to collect overseas translated editions of Australian authors.<ref>Rees, Lu (1981). "In the beginning (Reprinted from issue 1, 1981)." Notes, Books and Authors, 27th issue, 2005, page 5. "...one of the Librarians from the Canberra Public Library Service (CPLS) rang me and asked, ‘What are you doing about the International Year of the Child?’... if I could throw in a personal idea, it would be to emphasise the ‘International’ and try to get foreign editions of our own authors’ work in the children's field."</ref>
In 1980, Belle Alderman first suggested that the collection, which had outgrown the home of Lu Rees, could be housed at the Canberra College of Advanced Education (now the [[University of Canberra]]), where it could be accessed by students and researchers.<ref>Rees, Lu (1981). "In the beginning (Reprinted from issue 1, 1981)." Notes, Books and Authors, 27th issue, 2005, pages 3-5. "...we were discussing possibilities and tossing ideas around when Belle Alderman came into the fray with a request that she might be permitted to put the whole question before the authorities at the Canberra College of Advanced Education Library for, speaking personally, she would like to have the whole collection – books and files – available for reference and study by her students in Children's Literature here at the College."</ref> In the same year, the Library of the Canberra College of Advanced Education, under Chief Librarian the late Victor Crittenden O.A.M. (first Chair of the Lu Rees Archives Management Committee),<ref>Fletcher, Lynn (27 October 2005). "Lu Rees Archives Award." Notes, Books and Authors, 27th issue, 2005, page 20. "The Lu Rees Archives Committee was formed in 1983 by volunteers from The Children's Book Council Australian Capital Territory Branch, the CCAE library and teaching staff. Victor was its first chair."</ref> agreed to house the collection, [[Cataloguing|catalogue]] the resources and provide in kind support. At the time of handing over in July 1980, the collection became known as the Lu Rees Archives, after its founder.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article125610615 |title=Lu Rees Collection to college. |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |date=16 July 1980 |accessdate=26 September 2014 |page=11 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> The collection then held around 1000 books and 50 research files on authors and illustrators. In 1981 Australian publishers agreed to donate their children's books, a practice which has continued.<ref>Lu Rees Archives Website. [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/about/achievements-awards/timeline Timeline of achievements] Retrieved 12 July 2011.</ref>
Lu Rees, who received both an [[M.B.E.]] (in 1964) <ref>It's An Honour website, 2011. [http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=1086987&search_type=advanced&showInd=true Search Australian Honours Advanced Search : REES, Lucy Frances Harvey, The Order of the British Empire - Member (Civil)]. Retrieved 5 September 2011.</ref> and was created a member of the [[Order of Australia]] (A.M.) (in 1983)<ref>It's An Honour website, 2011. [http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=870336&search_type=advanced&showInd=true Search Australian Honours Advanced Search : REES, Lucy Frances Harvey, Member of the Order of Australia]. Retrieved 5 September 2011.</ref> for her services to [[children's literature]], died on 23 January 1983. Posthumously, Mrs Rees was awarded the [[Dromkeen Medal]] for services to children's literature.<ref>[http://www.scholastic.com.au/common/dromkeen/medal.asp Scholastic - Dromkeen Medal]</ref><ref>Stones, Rebecca (5 July 2005). [http://www.canberra.edu.au/monitor-archive/reports/20050705_LuRees.htm "Medals crown renown book collection"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406004131/http://www.canberra.edu.au/monitor-archive/reports/20050705_LuRees.htm |date=6 April 2012 }} Monitor (Newspaper of the University of Canberra), 5 July 2005 Retrieved 12 July 2011. "Last month, Lu Rees' sons, John and Lauron Rees, presented three medals to the University's Lu Rees Archives: a 1964 Order of the British Empire; a 1983 Order of Australia; and the 1983 inaugural Dromkeen Award."</ref>
===Management===
Since 1983, the Archives has been managed by the [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/about/management Lu Rees Archives Management Committee], members of which include representatives of the local and national [[Children's Book Council of Australia]], the [[University of Canberra Library]], [[National Library of Australia|national]] and public libraries and tertiary institutions in Canberra, as well as those managing the Archives and its activities. [[Children's Book Council of Australia|The Children's Book Council of Australia]] ACT Branch took over management of the Archives in 1990. The following year, the University and [[Children's Book Council of Australia|The Children's Book Council of Australia]] ACT Branch signed a formal agreement outlining roles and responsibilities, and the agreement was renewed in 2003.<ref>University of Canberra ; The Children's Book Council of Australia, ACT Branch (2003). "Agreement between the University of Canberra (‘the University’) and the Children's Book Council of Australia, ACT Branch Inc. (‘the ACT Book Council’) regarding the Lu Rees Archive of Children's Literature (‘the Archives’)."</ref> Up until 1989, when the University of Canberra Library was restructured, part-time staffing was available from the Library, and until a part-time position funded by [[Children's Book Council of Australia|The Children's Book Council of Australia]] began in 1995, administration of the Archives was undertaken by volunteers.<ref>Lu Rees Archive Website. [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/about/achievements-awards/timeline "Timeline of achievements"] Retrieved 12 July 2011.</ref> Management of the Archives is guided by the [https://web.archive.org/web/20120406003352/http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/attachments/pdf/StratPlan2011-15Final.pdf Lu Rees Archives Strategic Plan].
An honorary position of Collections Development Manager has existed since 1990 and [http://www.canberra.edu.au/expert/index.cfm?event=expert.detail&expertid=9551 Dr Belle Alderman], Emeritus Professor of Children's Literature, has occupied this position since its establishment.
==Collections==
An outline of the collection development objectives can be found in the current [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lurees/attachments/pdf/LuReesCollectionPolicy-2.pdf collection development policy], the Lu Rees Archives of Australian Children's Literature Strategic Plan,<ref>The Strategic Plan Sub-Committee [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/attachments/pdf/StratPlan2011-15Final.pdf "Lu Rees Archives of Australian Children's Literature Strategic Plan 2011-2015"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406003352/http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/attachments/pdf/StratPlan2011-15Final.pdf |date=6 April 2012 }}, pages 9-10. Retrieved 12 July 2011.</ref> and on the webpage [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/searching/item-types ‘List of item types held at the archives.’] The Lu Rees Archives has collected material by and about Australian children's book authors and illustrators, including [[manuscripts]], [[Illustration|artworks]], [[Children's literature|books]] (over 20,000 works, including over 2400 translations in more than 53 languages), [[Realia (library science)|artifacts]], [[Reference work|reference material]], [[thesis|theses]], [[rare books]], [[Periodical publication|periodicals]], and over [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lurees/searching 390 research files] featuring thirty different categories of materials. The Archives houses two publishers' archives, the [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/searching/special_collections/mcvitty-archive Walter McVitty Books] (donated in 2000) and [[Omnibus Books]] (donated in 2004), and has extensive photographic and audio material relating to Australian children's literature.<ref>Lu Rees Archive Website. [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/about/achievements-awards/timeline "Timeline of achievements"] Retrieved 12 July 2011.</ref> An ongoing project to develop 'Artwork Frameworks' to record artwork held by the Archive to aid with cataloguing and research began in 2009.<ref>Alderman, Belle ; Gamlen, Belinda (2010). [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/attachments/pdf/LRAAnnualReport2010FINAL.pdf "Lu Rees Archives Annual Report : 2010"], page 10. Retrieved 5 September 2011. "The artwork frameworks enable the Archives to gain physical and intellectual control over artwork held by the Archives; achieve a record of holdings; ensure easy storage and retrieval."</ref> An aim of the Archives is to collect all the individual editions of published works.<ref>The Lu Rees Archive Management Committee [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lurees/attachments/pdf/LuReesCollectionPolicy-2.pdf "The Lu Rees Archive of Australian Literature Collection Policy"], page 4. Retrieved 5 September 2011. "To fulfil its purpose as set out in 1.2 above, the Lu Rees Archives aims: 2.1.1 to build complete collections of significant authors and illustrators works."</ref>
==Significance==
*Since the year 2000, The Lu Rees Archive has been a contributor to [[AustLit|AustLit: The Australian Literature Resource]], originally providing 12,000 bibliographic records (including indexed reviews and articles on Australian children's literature).<ref>Alderman, Belle ; Gamlen, Belinda (2010). [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/attachments/pdf/LRAAnnualReport2010FINAL.pdf "Lu Rees Archives Annual Report : 2010"], page 4. Retrieved 12 July 2011. "In 2000, the Archives initially provided 12,000 bibliographic records and thereafter has indexed works by and about children's and young adult literature, thereby adding to the knowledge base of Australian children's literature."</ref><ref>AustLit : The Australian Literature Resource Website. [http://www.austlit.edu.au/specialistDatasets/ChildLit/LuReesCollections "Lu Rees bibliographical records."] Retrieved 12 July 2011.</ref> *To assist researchers, the Archives staff have created unique [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/searching/special_collections/author_finding_aids Author Finding Aids] and in 2010, the Archives "assisted 393 clients who visited or contacted the archives".<ref>Alderman, Belle ; Gamlen, Belinda (2010). [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/attachments/pdf/LRAAnnualReport2010FINAL.pdf "Lu Rees Archives Annual Report : 2010"], page 8. Retrieved 12 July 2011.</ref> *The Archives have presented a number of significant events celebrating Australian children's authors and their works, including: **In 2001, the Archives established the annual 'Walter McVitty Lectures,' sponsored by the [[National museum of australia|National Museum of Australia]],<ref>Alderman, Belle ; Meyers, Marlene (2001). [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lurees/attachments/pdf/LRA-annual-report-2001.11.pdf "Lu Rees Archives Annual Report 2001"], page 5. Retrieved 5 September 2011. "The Lu Rees Archives Management Committee established the annual Walter McVitty Lecture to commemorate this individual's significant contribution to Australian children's literature. The National Museum of Australia will sponsor this annual lecture, with the first to be delivered by Mem Fox on 25 October 2002 at the National Museum of Australia."</ref> which ran for three years ([[Mem Fox]] 2002, [[Morris Gleitzman]] 2003,<ref>National Museum of Australia website, 2003. [http://www.nma.gov.au/media/media_releases_by_year/2003/23_october_2003_childrens_writer_gleitzman Children's writer Gleitzman visits Museum]. Retrieved 5 September 2011.</ref> and [[Emily Rodda]] 2005<ref>National Museum of Australia Website, 2006. [http://www.nma.gov.au/about_us/nma_corporate_documents/annual_report/05_06/part_5/appendix_6_conferences/ National Museum of Australia : Annual Report - Appendix 6 : Conferences] Retrieved 5 September 2011.</ref>). **In 2007, The Words... Pictures... Book! Exhibition.<ref>Lu Rees Archives Website. [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/about/news-events/past-events/items/wpb "Words... Pictures... Book! Exhibition."] Retrieved 12 July 2011. "Our Words... Pictures... Book! exhibition was held at the Civic Library from 7th August until 5th October, 2007."</ref> **In 2011, a celebration of Australian children's books in translation featuring [[Emily Rodda]], an exhibition of Archives original artwork and cataloguing of 470 books in 30 languages.<ref>Hardy, Karen (21 March 2011). [http://www.canberratimes.com.au/news/lifestyle/entertainment/books/united-for-childrens-delight/2109088.aspx United for children's delight] The Canberra Times. Retrieved 12 July 2011.</ref><ref>Lu Rees Archives Website. [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/emily-rodda Emily Rodda Event 2011 : Children's books unite the world] Retrieved 12 July 2011.</ref> *In 2009, a report on behalf of the National Executive of The Children's Book Council of Australia by Marj Kirkland, found the Archives provided an "exceptional repository of knowledge and heritage related to Australian children's literature, whose existence should never be endangered".<ref>Alderman, Belle ; Gamlen, Belinda (2010). [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/attachments/pdf/LRAAnnualReport2010FINAL.pdf "Lu Rees Archives Annual Report : 2010"], page 12. Retrieved 12 July 2011. "The Kirkland report (August 2009), written on behalf of the CBCA National Executive, concluded that the Archives is an ‘exceptional repository of knowledge and heritage related to Australian children's literature, whose existence should never be endangered. Rather, more secure, greater ongoing funding should be sought to sustain it in perpetuity’."</ref> *In a significance report,<ref>Powell, Graeme (January 2011). "Lu Rees Archives of Australian children's literature : Assessment of significance.", January 2011.</ref> an external expert, Graeme Powell,<ref>National Library of Australia (October 2001). [http://www.nla.gov.au/pub/gateways/archive/53/p19a01.html "Graeme Powell – Distinguished achiever."] Gateways, National Library of Australia, No. 53, October 2001. Retrieved 12 July 2011.</ref> identified the significance of the Archives as follows: **its book collection post-1960 is comparable to National and State Libraries. **its collection of translated works are among Australia's strongest **its 400 comprehensive research files on authors and illustrators are "unmatched" in Australia. **its manuscripts and artworks feature Australia's most important creators and "is of considerable value to researchers studying the artistic development of particular illustrators." **its resources are open access and this is valued by researchers.
==Funding== *The National Executive of [[Children's Book Council of Australia|The Children's Book Council of Australia]] funds one part-time administrative officer, and the ACT Branch provides an annual donation.<ref>Alderman, Belle ; Gamlen, Belinda (2010). [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/attachments/pdf/LRAAnnualReport2010FINAL.pdf "Lu Rees Archives Annual Report : 2010"], page 4. Retrieved 12 July 2011. "We also acknowledge the annual donation of $1,000 from the ACT Branch of The Children's Book Council of Australia (CBCA). The CBCA's National Executive and National Council have funded, since 1993, the part-time position of the Lu Rees Archives Administrative Officer. This position provides 14 hours per week for 46 weeks of the year, thus enabling the Archives to manage, preserve and promote the collection."</ref> *Donations – In 1988, the Archives achieved [[deductible gift recipient]] status, with eligibility to receive gifts under the [http://www.arts.gov.au/tax_incentives/cgp Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program] including monetary donations (authors, illustrators and publishers can donate published and unpublished material under the program,<ref>Lu Rees Archives Website. [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/donations/cultural-gifts "Cultural gifts donations and the Lu Rees Archives."] Retrieved 12 July 2011.</ref> and by the year 2005, 117 publishers had donated material<ref>Alderman, Belle (2005). "Publishers’ support of the Lu Rees Archives." Notes, Books and Authors, 27th issue, 2005, page 12.</ref>). Members of the public also support the Archives with donations.<ref>Lu Rees Archives Website. [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/donations "Making donations."] Retrieved 12 July 2011.</ref> *In kind support for the archives has been offered by the University of Canberra, and is part of a formal agreement between the University Library and [[Children's Book Council of Australia|The Children's Book Council of Australia]].<ref>University of Canberra ; The Children's Book Council of Australia, ACT Branch (2003). "Agreement between the University of Canberra (‘the University’) and the Children's Book Council of Australia, ACT Branch Inc. (‘the ACT Book Council’) regarding the Lu Rees Archive of Children's Literature (‘the Archives’)."</ref> To secure the future of The Lu Rees Archives, "the Archives aims to create an endowment fund of $1,000,000 by 2020".<ref>The Strategic Plan Sub-Committee [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/attachments/pdf/StratPlan2011-15Final.pdf "Lu Rees Archives of Australian Children's Literature Strategic Plan 2011-2015"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406003352/http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/attachments/pdf/StratPlan2011-15Final.pdf |date=6 April 2012 }}, page 7. Retrieved 12 July 2011. "To secure this envisioned future, a stable income source, such as provided by an endowment fund, is a strategic goal of the Lu Rees Archives. Therefore, the Archives aims to create an endowment fund of $1,000,000 by 2020."</ref>
==Volunteers== The Archives has a strong [[Volunteering|volunteer]] body with various expertise who pursue specific projects (e.g. [[Media preservation|preservation of works]]) and progress the strategic plan. The volunteer program is permanent and essential to daily functioning of the Archive. Currently, the positions of Collections Development Manager, and Editor of the ‘Lu Rees Archives : Notes, Books and Authors’ Journal, are voluntary.<ref>The Strategic Plan Sub-Committee [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/attachments/pdf/StratPlan2011-15Final.pdf "Lu Rees Archives of Australian Children's Literature Strategic Plan 2011-2015"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406003352/http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/attachments/pdf/StratPlan2011-15Final.pdf |date=6 April 2012 }}, page 4-5. Retrieved 12 July 2011.</ref> In 2010, volunteers contributed over 2013 hours of unpaid work to the archives.<ref>Alderman, Belle ; Gamlen, Belinda (2010). [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/attachments/pdf/LRAAnnualReport2010FINAL.pdf "Lu Rees Archives Annual Report : 2010"], page 8-9. Retrieved 12 July 2011. "The 2013.28 hours worked by volunteers is equivalent to 287.6 days full time equivalent or over 12.5 months (based on a seven-hour day and an average of 23 working days in a month)."</ref>
==Publications== [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/publications/notes-books-authors ‘The Lu Rees Archives : Notes, Books and Authors’] (ISSN 0725-7015) journal, begun in 1981,<ref>Lu Rees Archives Website. [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/about/achievements-awards/timeline Timeline of achievements] Retrieved 12 July 2011.</ref> is published once per year and contains articles by authors, illustrators and publishers on children's literature, as well as news from the Archive ([http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/attachments/pdf/Jnl-Index-to-Iss-31-2009.pdf an index of the journal is available online]). The Archives [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/publications/annual-reports annual reports] and [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/publications/strategic_plans Strategic Plan] are available online.
==Access==
The Archives has an extensive website http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees, and information on how to access [http://www.canberra.edu.au/lu-rees/searching the catalogue and author/illustrator files online]. The Archives is open two days per week, and allows access at other times by appointment.
==See also== {{Portal|Australia|Children's literature}} *[[AustLit|AustLit: The Australian Literature Resource]] *[[Australian literature]] *[[:Category:Australian children's writers]] *[[Children's Book Council of Australia]] *[[Children's literature]] *[[University of Canberra Library]] *[[Aora Children's Literature Research Centre]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[https://www.canberra.edu.au/national-centre-for-australian-childrens-literature The National Centre for Australian Children's Literature Website] *[http://cbca.org.au The Children's Book Council of Australia] *[https://www.flickr.com/photos/lureesarchives/ Images of The Centre at Flickr.com] *[http://pandora.nla.gov.au/tep/24444 Lu Rees Archive Website] archived at [http://pandora.nla.gov.au/ Pandora] *Resources about [http://trove.nla.gov.au/book/result?q=%22Lu+Rees+Archive%22+OR+%22National+centre+for+australian+children%27s+literature%22 the Lu Rees Archives and NCALC] at [http://trove.nla.gov.au Trove]
