revision.comment: Rvt 2 edits by 107.0.114.13. Incorrectly changed spelling
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2018}}
[[File:Nunes Memo.pdf|thumb|page=3|Nunes memo]] [[File:Doj letter to nunes 180124.pdf|thumb|The U.S. Justice Department warned that the public release of a classified memo alleging abuses in FBI surveillance tactics would be "extraordinarily reckless without giving the Department and the FBI the opportunity to review the memorandum".<ref name="Jarrett"/>]]
The '''Nunes memo''' (formally titled '''''Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act Abuses at the Department of Justice and the Federal Bureau of Investigation''''')<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/our-columnists/why-were-the-democrats-so-worried-about-the-nunes-memo |title=Why Were the Democrats So Worried About the Nunes Memo? |last=Sorkin |first=Amy Davidson |date=February 2, 2018 |work=The New Yorker|access-date=February 3, 2018 |language=en |issn=0028-792X}}</ref> is a four-page memorandum written for [[U.S. Representative]] [[Devin Nunes]] by his staff and released to the public by the Republican-controlled committee on February 2, 2018. The memo alleges that the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) "may have relied on politically motivated or questionable sources" to obtain a [[United States Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court#FISA warrant|Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) warrant]] in October 2016 and in three subsequent renewals on Trump adviser [[Carter Page]] in the early phases of the FBI's investigation into [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]].<ref name="WaPo">{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-sought-release-of-classified-russia-memo-putting-him-at-odds-with-justice-department/2018/01/27/a00f2a4c-02bb-11e8-9d31-d72cf78dbeee_story.html |title=Trump sought release of classified Russia memo, putting him at odds with Justice Department |last=Parker |first=Ashley |date=January 27, 2018 |work=Washington Post|access-date=January 29, 2018 |last2=Helderman |first2=Rosalind S. |language=en-US |issn=0190-8286 |last3=Dawsey |first3=Josh |last4=Leonnig |first4=Carol D. |quote="investigation into Russian meddling," "written by staff members for House Intelligence Committee Chairman Rep. Devin Nunes (R-Calif.) and suggests that the FBI may have relied on politically motivated or questionable sources to justify its request for a secret surveillance warrant in the investigation’s early phase."}}</ref> On July 21, 2018, the Justice Department released heavily redacted versions of four FISA warrant applications for Carter Page which showed that key assertions made in the Nunes memo were false or misleading, corroborating the rebuttal made by Democrats.<ref>{{cite news |last=Savage |first=Charlie |authorlink=Charlie Savage|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/22/us/politics/how-a-trump-decision-revealed-a-gop-memos-shaky-foundation.html |title=How a Trump Decision Revealed a G.O.P. Memo’s Shaky Foundation|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=July 23, 2018}}</ref><ref name="auto1">{{cite web |last=Kris |first=David |author-link=David Kris |title=What to Make of the Carter Page FISA Applications |url=https://www.lawfareblog.com/what-make-carter-page-fisa-applications |publisher=Lawfare |date=July 21, 2018 |access-date=July 23, 2018}}</ref>
Nunes is the chairman of the [[House Intelligence Committee]] and a supporter of [[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act|FISA]] surveillance extension.<ref>{{cite web |accessdate=February 2, 2018 |title=Nunes Statement on Passage of FISA 702 Bill |url=https://intelligence.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=848 |date=January 11, 2018 |website=U.S. House of Representatives Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/01/devin-nunes-fbi-memo-controversy |title=Who is Devin Nunes and why is he sowing confusion in the Russia inquiry? |last=Yuhas |first=Alan |date=February 1, 2018 |website=the Guardian |language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=February 2, 2018 |quote=he has strongly supported government surveillance powers since he was elected in 2002 to Congress}}</ref> Former Trump campaign CEO and chief strategist [[Steve Bannon]] has described Nunes as Trump's second-strongest ally in Congress.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/24/magazine/how-devin-nunes-turned-the-house-intelligence-committee-inside-out.html|title=How Devin Nunes Turned the House Intelligence Committee Inside Out|first=Jason|last=Zengerle|date=April 24, 2018|publisher=|accessdate=May 6, 2018|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> In April 2017, Nunes stepped aside from chairing the House Intelligence Committee's Russia investigation while the House Ethics Committee conducted an inquiry into whether Nunes had violated applicable ethics rules with respect to his apparent secret coordination with White House officials. Nunes then began his own parallel secret investigation. The Ethics Committee investigation ended in December 2017, after which Nunes claimed that he had never recused himself.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/04/nunes-to-step-aside-from-russia-probe-236951 |title=Nunes steps aside from Russia probe}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/12/07/ethics-committee-clears-rep-devin-nunes-287125|title=Ethics Committee clears Rep. Devin Nunes}}</ref>
Republican legislators who favored public release of the memo argued that the memo presents evidence that a group of politically biased FBI employees abused the FISA warrant process for the purpose of undermining the [[Presidency of Donald Trump|Donald Trump presidency]].<ref name=realaim /> These congressmen alleged that there was excessive and improper dependence on the [[Trump–Russia dossier]], which was funded in part by the [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016|Clinton campaign]] and [[Democratic National Committee]], when the Justice Department applied to the FISA court to conduct electronic surveillance on Trump aide [[Carter Page]] during the course of the campaign.<ref name=EmmonsAaronson/><ref name=Chang /> Political allies of Donald Trump attempted to use the memo to pivot attention away from the [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–present)|Special Counsel investigation]] of the Trump presidential campaign's role in [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]].<ref name=realaim /> Prior to release of the memo, news media reported that Trump told his associates that release of the memo would discredit the investigation.<ref name=Liptak /><ref>{{cite news |title=Trump moves toward releasing memo he hopes will undermine Russia probe |first1=Kevin |last1=Liptak |first2=Kaitlan |last2=Collins |first3=Sara |last3=Murray |first4=Dan |last4=Merica |work=CNN |date=February 2, 2018 |access-date=February 2, 2018 |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/02/01/politics/nunes-memo-donald-trump/index.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Trump telling people Nunes memo will discredit Mueller probe: report |first1=Max |last1=Greenwood |work=The Hill |date=February 1, 2018 |access-date=February 2, 2018 |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/371791-trump-telling-people-nunes-memo-will-discredit-mueller-probe-report}}</ref>
A social media campaign, under the hashtag #ReleaseTheMemo, emerged in mid-January 2018 to publicly release the memo despite some of its classified contents. Journalist and national security advocacy groups reported that Russian-linked bots on [[Twitter]] helped spread the controversial hashtag.<ref name="businessinsider">{{Cite news |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/release-the-memo-campaign-russia-linked-twitter-accounts-2018-1 |title=Russia-linked Twitter accounts are working overtime to help Devin Nunes and WikiLeaks |work=Business Insider|access-date=January 25, 2018 |language=en}}</ref><ref name="newsweek">{{cite web |url=http://www.newsweek.com/release-memo-russian-bots-campaign-democrats-789317 |title=Russian Bots Might Be Behind Controversial #ReleaseTheMemo Campaign, Democrats Say |author=Ryan Sit |date=January 24, 2018 |website=[[Newsweek]]|access-date=January 26, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Dilanian">{{Cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/right-wing-demand-releasethememo-endorsed-russian-bots-trolls-n839141 |title=Right-wing demand to #ReleaseTheMemo endorsed by Russian bots, trolls|access-date=January 26, 2018 |publisher=NBC News |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2018/02/04/trump-twitter-russians-release-the-memo-216935 |title=How Twitter Bots and Trump Fans Made #ReleaseTheMemo Go Viral |work=POLITICO Magazine|access-date=February 5, 2018}}</ref>
Trump approved release of the Republican document over the objections of the FBI and the [[U.S. Intelligence Community]].<ref name="Leonnig">{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/trump-expected-to-approve-release-of-memo-following-redactions-requested-by-intelligence-officials/2018/02/01/a55210e6-0757-11e8-8777-2a059f168dd2_story.html |title=Trump to approve release of GOP memo Friday over objections from law enforcement, intelligence community |publisher=[[The Washington Post]] |date=February 1, 2018 |accessdate=February 2, 2018 |last=Leonnig |first=Carol |last2=Dawsey |first2=Josh}}</ref> The FBI issued a rare statement expressing "grave concerns" about factual omissions and the accuracy of the memo.<ref name="Leonnig" /><ref name="Lucas">{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2018/01/31/582148612/fbi-warns-of-grave-concerns-about-accuracy-of-gop-snooping-memo |title=FBI Warns Of 'Grave Concerns' About 'Accuracy' Of GOP Snooping Memo |publisher=[[NPR]] |date=January 31, 2018 |accessdate=February 2, 2018 |last=Lucas |first=Ryan |last2=Neuman |first2=Scott}}</ref> Within Congress, anticipation of the release of the memo sparked controversy, mainly along political lines. House Republicans released the memo on February 2, 2018.
Democrats on the House Intelligence Committee prepared a classified 10 page rebuttal of claims in the Nunes memo, which was initially blocked for release. After the Nunes memo was released to the public, the House Intelligence Committee voted unanimously to release the Democrats' memo.<ref name=":0">{{cite news |last1=Raju |first1=Manu |last2=Herb |first2=Jeremy |title=House Intelligence Committee unanimously votes to release Democratic memo |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/02/05/politics/democratic-memo-release-house-intelligence/index.html |accessdate=February 7, 2018 |work=CNN |date=February 6, 2018}}</ref> On February 9, Trump blocked release of the Democrats' memo, saying the committee should [[Sanitization (classified information)|redact]] classified and sensitive material before releasing it to the public.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/09/us/politics/trump-blocks-release-of-memo-rebutting-republican-claims.html |title=Trump Blocks Release of Memo Rebutting Republican Claims |last=Shear |first=Michael D. |date=February 9, 2018 |work=The New York Times|access-date=February 11, 2018 |last2=Fandos |first2=Nicholas |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/2018/02/09/584699083/trump-will-not-immediately-release-democratic-memo-suggests-revisions |title=Trump Will Not Immediately Release Democratic Memo, Suggests Revisions |work=NPR.org|access-date=February 11, 2018 |language=en}}</ref> A redacted version of the Democratic memo was ultimately released on February 24.<ref>{{cite news |authorlink= |author=Jeremy Herb |title=Democratic intelligence memo released with redactions |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/02/24/politics/democratic-memo-house-intelligence-released/index.html |work=CNN.com |date=February 24, 2018 |accessdate=February 24, 2018}}</ref> {{clear left}}
==Contents== The memo states that a<!-- This was not the first FISA warrant for Page. He was subject to one in 2014. --> FISA warrant on Carter Page was sought and obtained on October 21, 2016, and that there were three subsequent 90-day renewals. The memo notes that FISA submissions are classified information.
The memo “raise[s] concern as to the legitimacy and legality” of the FISA application process relating to Page, and that [[probable cause]] was not made in the warrant application. It makes five main points. First it alleges that the [[Trump–Russia dossier|Steele dossier]] "formed an essential part of the Carter Page FISA application." The memo asserted that [[Christopher Steele]] was paid $160,000 by the Democratic National Committee and the Clinton campaign, and that this information was not disclosed in the initial October 2016 FISA application or subsequent renewals.<ref name="6 takeaways">{{cite web |last=Morrow |first=Adrian |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/us-politics/trump-memo-explainer/article37833630/ |title=6 takeaways from the newly released Trump-Russia memo |date=February 2, 2018 |work=The Globe and Mail |accessdate=February 4, 2018}}</ref> However, the FBI's application for a FISA warrant did describe, in a footnote, the origins and political background of the dossier,<ref name="WaPo political influence">{{cite web |last=Nakashima |first=Ellen |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/justice-dept-told-court-of-sources-political-bias-in-request-to-wiretap-ex-trump-campaign-aide-officials-say/2018/02/02/caecfa86-0852-11e8-8777-2a059f168dd2_story.html |title=Justice Dept. told court of source's political influence in request to wiretap ex-Trump campaign aide, officials say |date=February 2, 2018 |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=February 5, 2018}}</ref> a fact conceded by Nunes and other Republican leaders on February 5, after the memo's release.<ref name="footnotePolitico">{{cite news |last1=Cheney |first1=Kyle |title=Republicans concede key FBI 'footnote' in Carter Page warrant |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/02/05/fbi-footnote-carter-page-warrant-390795 |work=Politico |date=February 5, 2018}}</ref>
Second, the memo alleges that the FISA application relied "extensively" on a ''[[Yahoo! News]]'' report from September 2016 by [[Michael Isikoff]], which referenced Page's July 2016 trip to Moscow and used information from Steele.<ref name=yahoo>{{cite web |url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/yahoo-news-michael-isikoff-describes-crucial-meeting-cited-nunes-memo-231005733.html |title=Yahoo News' Michael Isikoff describes crucial meeting cited in Nunes memo |publisher= |accessdate=February 6, 2018}}</ref> It asserts that the article was "derived from information leaked by Steele himself to Yahoo News." Isikoff has stated that the information he got from Steele was actually information that the FBI already had. He also described Steele as serious and credible.<ref name=yahoo/>
Third, the memo accuses Steele of being biased against the candidacy of Donald Trump, stating he was "desperate" and "passionate" that Trump would lose. It goes on to say [[Bruce Ohr]] knew about this bias and that it was not reflected in the FISA applications.<ref name="6 takeaways"/><ref name="qz.com">{{cite web |last=de Haldevang |first=Max |url=https://qz.com/1196883/a-summary-of-the-gop-memos-claims-about-fbi-wrongdoing/ |title=Here's what the GOP memo claims about FBI wrongdoing |work=Quartz |date=February 2, 2018 |accessdate=February 4, 2018}}</ref> Ohr however did not work on counter intelligence matters and had no role in obtaining the FISA warrants on Page.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/why-the-nunes-memo-takes-aim-at-a-justice-department-official-specializing-in-gangs-and-drugs/2018/02/02/82e836e8-0847-11e8-94e8-e8b8600ade23_story.html |title=Why the Nunes memo takes aim at a Justice Dept. official specializing in gangs and drugs |first1=Matt |last1=Zapotosky |first2=Beth |last2=Reinhard |date=February 2, 2018 |accessdate=February 6, 2018 |work=The Washington Post}}</ref>
The memo's fourth point quotes [[Bill Priestap]] saying that the corroboration of the Steele dossier was in its "infancy" in October 2016 during the FISA application. The memo further alleges that [[Andrew McCabe]] testified that "no surveillance warrant would have been sought from the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court (FISC) without the Steele dossier information."<ref name="Day AP">{{cite news |last1=Day |first1=Chad |title=What the GOP Memo Says (And Doesn't Say) |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2018-02-03/what-the-gop-memo-says-and-doesnt-say |accessdate=February 4, 2018 |work=U.S. News & World Report |agency=Associated Press |date=February 2, 2018}}</ref> Other members of the House Intelligence Committee and sources close to the matter have stated that the Nunes memo "misquoted" and "mischaracterized" McCabe's testimony, which was given in private and has not been made public.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.realclearpolitics.com/video/2018/02/02/rep_swalwell_nunes_memo_misquotes_mccabes_statement_about_steele_dossierfisa_warrant.html |title=Rep. Swalwell: Nunes Memo Misquotes McCabe's Statement About Steele Dossier/FISA Warrant |work=RealClearPolitics |accessdate=February 6, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/doubt-cast-upon-nunes-memos-bombshell-claim-about-andrew-mccabes-testimony-on-trump-dossier/article/2647990 |title=Doubt cast upon Nunes memo's bombshell claim about Andrew McCabe's testimony on Trump dossier |first=Diana Stancy |last=Correll |work=Washington Examiner |accessdate=February 6, 2018}}</ref>
The memo also confirms that the spark for the FBI investigation into potential collusion between Trump's campaign and the Russians was not the Steele dossier, but rather the comments made by Trump adviser [[George Papadopoulos]], who told an Australian diplomat in May 2016 that the Russians possessed "dirt" on [[Hillary Clinton]] in the form of hacked emails.<ref name="auto">{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/ct-gop-memo-papadopoulos-20180202-story.html |title=Sentence on Papadopoulos in GOP memo may undercut efforts to discredit Russia probe |first1=Karen |last1=Tumulty |first2=Rosalind S. |last2=Helderman |website=Chicago Tribune |accessdate=February 11, 2018}}</ref> That confirmation contradicts earlier claims by some that the investigation had been triggered by the Steele dossier.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Cassidy |first1=John |title=The Nunes Memo Undermines the Right’s Trump-Russia Conspiracy Theory |url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/our-columnists/the-nunes-memo-undermines-the-rights-trump-russia-conspiracy-theory |work=The New Yorker |date=February 2, 2018 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Sheth |first1=Sonam |title=We now know the tipping point that prompted the FBI to launch its Trump-Russia investigation |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/fbi-opened-russia-probe-after-papadopoulos-told-australian-diplomat-of-clinton-dirt-2017-12 |accessdate=March 3, 2018 |work=Business Insider |date=December 30, 2017}}</ref> The memo notes that Papadopoulos is mentioned in the Page FISA application, and says "there is no evidence of any cooperation or conspiracy between Page and Papadopoulos." It also says the FBI's Russian investigation was opened by [[Peter Strzok]], who is accused of having "a clear bias against Trump and in favor of Clinton."<ref name="6 takeaways"/><ref name="Day AP"/>
The memo also shows that the FISA warrant on Page was renewed three times. In each instance, the FBI had to show the signing judge that the warrant had merit.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Palma |first1=Bethania |title=Nunes Memo Drops and Flops |url=https://www.snopes.com/2018/02/02/nunes-memo-drops-flops/ |website=Snopes |publisher=Snopes |accessdate=February 6, 2018}}</ref><ref name=Shipler>{{cite web |url=https://www.thenation.com/article/the-nunes-memo-shows-real-problems-with-the-fbi-but-not-the-ones-the-gop-thinks/ |title=The Nunes Memo Shows Real Problems With the FBI, but Not the Ones the GOP Thinks |publisher=[[The Nation]] |date=February 5, 2018 |accessdate=February 6, 2018 |last=Shipler |first=David}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2018/02/nunes-memo-impact/552368/ |title=How the Nunes Memo Harms Intelligence Oversight |publisher=[[The Atlantic (magazine)|The Atlantic]] |accessdate=February 6, 2018}}</ref><ref name=Megerian>{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-na-pol-congress-russia-memo-20180205-story.html |title=You thought the memo drama was over? It's just heating up |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=February 5, 2018 |accessdate=February 6, 2018 |last=Megerian |first=Chris}}</ref> News accounts in 2017 indicated that because of the nature of his ties to Russia, Page had been under FBI scrutiny and had already been the subject of a [[Evgeny Buryakov|FISA warrant in 2014]], at least two years before the Trump campaign.<ref>{{cite news |last=Phillips |first=Ariella |date=August 3, 2017 |title=Former Trump adviser Carter Page under FISA warrant since 2014: Report |url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/former-trump-adviser-carter-page-under-fisa-warrant-since-2014-report/article/2630576 |work=[[The Washington Examiner]] |location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Perez |first1=Evan |last2=Brown |first2=Pamela |last3=Prokupecz |first3=Shimon |date=August 4, 2017 |title=One year into the FBI's Russia investigation, Mueller is on the Trump money trail |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/08/03/politics/mueller-investigation-russia-trump-one-year-financial-ties/index.html?CNNPolitics=Tw |work=CNN.com |location=Atlanta, GA}}</ref>
Finally, the memo asserts that former FBI Director James Comey testified to Congress that the Steele dossier was "salacious and unverified." However, Comey's prepared remarks show that he was referring specifically to "some personally sensitive aspects" of the dossier, not the entire dossier.<ref>{{cite news |title=READ: James Comey's prepared testimony |url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/06/07/politics/james-comey-memos-testimony/index.html |accessdate=February 28, 2018 |work=CNN |date=June 8, 2017}}</ref>
==Background==
The memo was produced by a small group of House Republicans and staff, led by Devin Nunes, as part of an investigation into how the FBI used the [[Trump–Russia dossier]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/12/20/house-republicans-quietly-investigate-doj-fbi-310121 |title=House Republicans quietly investigate perceived corruption at DOJ, FBI |work=Politico |date=December 20, 2017}}</ref> Democratic committee members were not informed about the investigation into the FBI or the preparation of the memo, a possible violation of committee rules.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Herb |first1=Jeremy |title=Schiff accuses Nunes of altering memo before sending to White House |url=http://www.fox10tv.com/story/37398915/nunes-clashes-with-democrats-over-fbi-memo-review-white-house-consultation |publisher=Fox 10 |date=February 1, 2018}}</ref> Adam Schiff, the [[ranking member]] of the House Intelligence Committee, said that Nunes had not read all of the relevant source material, although Nunes had argued for months that the FBI and DOJ had taken part in a conspiracy.<ref name="newsweek.com">{{cite web |author=Ryan Sit |url=http://www.newsweek.com/devin-nunes-adam-schiff-secret-memo-release-memo-794957 |title=Nunes "cherry-picked" details for the secret memo without even reading the source material: Top Democrat |date=January 30, 2018 |newspaper=Newsweek |accessdate=January 30, 2018}}</ref>
Nunes had previously recused himself from the committee's investigation into Russia's interference in U.S. elections<ref name="newsweek.com"/> due to a House ethics investigation into Nunes' coordination with the Trump administration. The House Ethics Committee stated that "Nunes may have made unauthorized disclosures of classified information, in violation of House Rules, law, regulations, or other standards of conduct" (the ethics investigation ended when the committee was unable to obtain the relevant classified information).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/house-intelligence-chairman-devin-nunes-recuses-himself-from-russia-probe/2017/04/06/8122b5bc-1ad2-11e7-855e-4824bbb5d748_story.html |title=House Intelligence Chairman Devin Nunes recuses himself from Russia probe |first=Karoun |last=Demirjian |date=April 6, 2017 |newspaper=Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://theweek.com/speedreads/751784/report-ethics-investigation-into-nunes-ended-because-panel-couldnt-gain-access-classified-info |title=Report: Ethics investigation into Nunes ended because panel couldn't gain access to classified info |date=January 29, 2018 |work=The Week}}</ref> However, after offering to step aside from the investigation into Russian interference, Nunes began his own "parallel" investigation, whose purpose appeared to be to undermine the original ongoing investigation.<ref>{{cite web |author=Natasha Bertrand |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/nunes-russia-investigation-subpoenas-fusion-gps-trump-2017-10 |title=Devin Nunes appears to be running a 'parallel' Russia probe without Democrats' consent |work=Business Insider |date=October 10, 2017}}</ref>
Since January 18 a growing number of Republicans began calling for the release of the memo.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Schwartz |first1=Sam |title=What Is the Nunes Memo? Controversial Intelligence Document About Trump Campaign Surveillance Spawns #Releasethemem |url=http://www.newsweek.com/nunes-memo-donald-trump-intelligence-release-793571 |issue=January 29, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Hill119">{{Cite news |url=http://thehill.com/policy/national-security/369721-gop-reps-demand-release-of-shocking-surveillance-memo |title=GOP reps demand release of 'shocking' surveillance memo |publisher=The Hill |date=January 19, 2018}}</ref>
Adam Schiff released a statement and a letter to Nunes on January 31, 2018, stating that Nunes had "made material changes to the memo he sent to White House – changes not approved by the Committee" and that the White House was "reviewing a document the Committee has not approved for release."<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/schiff-accuses-nunes-of-altering-memo-before-sharing-it-with-trump-for-release/2018/01/31/251423c8-06fe-11e8-8777-2a059f168dd2_story.html |title=Schiff accuses Nunes of altering memo before sharing it with Trump for release |last=Demirjian |first=Karoun |date=January 31, 2018 |work=Washington Post|access-date=February 1, 2018 |language=en-US |issn=0190-8286}}</ref> In response [[Peter T. King|Peter King]], who also sits on the Intelligence Committee, stated, "My understanding is this was agreed on beforehand among Republicans. There's one small part in the memo which in no way affects the substance in the memo." He said it involved removing only "three or four words" and came at the request of the FBI.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Greenwood |first1=Max |title=Pete King: Nunes changed ‘one small part’ of memo, did not affect its substance |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/house/371775-peter-king-nunes-changed-one-small-part-of-memo-but-did-not-affect-its |accessdate=February 2, 2018 |work=The Hill |date=January 2, 2018}}</ref>
===Social media influence===
A social media campaign under the [[hashtag]] "#ReleaseTheMemo" emerged on January 19, 2018,<ref>{{cite web |accessdate=February 2, 2018 |title=Trending Topics del viernes 19 de enero en Worldwide |url=http://www.trendinalia.com/twitter-trending-topics/globales/globales-180119.html |website=www.trendinalia.com}}</ref> to publicly release the memo despite some of its classified contents.
According to the ''Hamilton 68'' project run by the bipartisan [[Alliance for Securing Democracy]] (ASD) which tracks Russian propaganda efforts on Twitter, the hashtag was promoted by Russian twitter bot accounts, with a 230,000 percent spike in the promotion of the hashtag by these accounts.<ref name=newsweek/><ref name=businessinsider/><ref name=Dilanian/> [[Clint Watts]], one of the founding researchers of ASD, said the social media campaign started trending after [[Julian Assange]] advocated for the memo's release, which was then repeated by Russian influence networks.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Elder |first1=Miriam |last2=Warzel |first2=Charlie |url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/miriamelder/stop-blaming-russian-bots-for-everything |title=Stop Blaming Russian Bots For Everything |work=BuzzFeed News |accessdate=April 24, 2018 |date=February 28, 2018 |quote='When Julian Assange says something, Russian influence networks always repeat it,' Watts said. 'So he weighed in on the Nunes memo; that's what made it trend.'}}</ref> Twitter stated that a "preliminary analysis of available geographical data for tweets with the hashtag #ReleaseTheMemo ... has not identified any significant activity connected to Russia with respect to tweets posting original content to this hashtag."<ref name=Dwoskin>{{cite web |last1=Dwoskin |first1=Elizabeth |last2=Timberg |first2=Craig |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2018/01/31/lawmakers-press-social-media-companies-again-on-the-forces-behind-the-releasethememo-campaign/ |title=Lawmakers press social media companies — again — on the forces behind the #ReleaseTheMemo campaign |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=January 31, 2018 |accessdate=February 1, 2018}}</ref><ref name=Gadde>{{cite web |url=https://democrats-intelligence.house.gov/uploadedfiles/twitter_response_jan_26.pdf |title=Letter to Adam Schiff and Dianne Feinstein |publisher=[[Twitter]] |date=January 26, 2018 |accessdate=February 3, 2018 |first=Vijaya |last=Gadde}}</ref> According to an analysis by CNN the hashtag was pushed by over a thousand newly created accounts, of which 460 were without a profile picture. CNN also noted that the hashtag was promoted by prominent American conservatives and Republicans, including [[Donald Trump Jr.]] and [[Mark Meadows (North Carolina politician)|Mark Meadows]].<ref name=cnn>{{Cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2018/01/24/media/releasethememo-twitter-accounts/index.html |title=Hundreds of newly created Twitter accounts pushed #ReleaseTheMemo |last=O'Sullivan |first=Donie |work=CNNMoney |access-date=January 26, 2018}}</ref>
===Historical background=== {{Wikisource|HPSCI Meeting Transcript (January 29, 2018)}} [[Carter Page]] originally came to the attention of the FBI counterintelligence unit in 2013, prior to his becoming a Trump campaign adviser, when the unit learned that [[Evgeny Buryakov|Russian spies]] were trying to use Page as a source of information and to recruit him as an agent; this resulted in Page being interviewed by the FBI in June 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/04/us/politics/carter-page-trump-russia.html |title=Russian Spies Tried to Recruit Carter Page Before He Advised Trump |first=Adam |last=Goldman |date=April 4, 2017 |newspaper=New York Times}}</ref><ref name=Nakashima>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/fbi-obtained-fisa-warrant-to-monitor-former-trump-adviser-carter-page/2017/04/11/620192ea-1e0e-11e7-ad74-3a742a6e93a7_story.html |title=FBI obtained FISA warrant to monitor Trump adviser Carter Page |first1=Ellen |last1=Nakashima |first2=Devlin |last2=Barrett |first3=Adam |last3=Entous |date=April 11, 2017 |newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=McCarthy |first1=Tom |title=Who is Carter Page, the Trump ex-adviser at the center of the memo furore? |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/02/who-is-carter-page-trump-ex-adviser-memo-furore-russia-fbi |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=February 4, 2018}}</ref> He was under secret intelligence surveillance beginning in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/08/03/politics/mueller-investigation-russia-trump-one-year-financial-ties/index.html|title=One year into the FBI's Russia investigation, Mueller is on the Trump money trail|first=Evan Perez, Pamela Brown and Shimon Prokupecz,|last=CNN|publisher=|accessdate=April 30, 2018}}</ref> Page claimed that the information he provided to the Russians was innocuous.<ref name=Nakashima /> Page was the subject of at least one FISA warrant, going back to 2014, when he was alleged to have been colluding with the Russian government or knowingly working as an agent on its behalf.<ref>{{cite news |last=Phillips |first=Ariella |date=August 3, 2017 |title=Former Trump adviser Carter Page under FISA warrant since 2014: Report |url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/former-trump-adviser-carter-page-under-fisa-warrant-since-2014-report/article/2630576 |work=Washington Examiner |location=Washington, DC}}</ref><ref name=Harding>{{cite web |url=https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2018/02/03/carter-page-nunes-memo-216934 |title=Why Carter Page Was Worth Watching |publisher=[[Politico]] |date=February 3, 2018 |accessdate=February 6, 2018 |last=Harding |first=Luke}}</ref> In March 2016, then-candidate Donald Trump listed the little-known Page as one of his foreign policy advisers.
In a May 2016 meeting in London, Trump foreign policy adviser [[George Papadopoulos]] told the [[Australian High Commissioner to the United Kingdom]], [[Alexander Downer]], that the Russians possessed "dirt" on [[Hillary Clinton]] in the form of hacked emails.<ref name="auto"/> Two months later, Australian officials passed this information to American officials. This began the inquiry into Trump's relationship to Russia.<ref name=nyt-20171230>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/30/us/politics/how-fbi-russia-investigation-began-george-papadopoulos.html |title=How the Russia Inquiry Began: A Campaign Aide, Drinks and Talk of Political Dirt |work=[[The New York Times]] |last1=LaFraniere |first1=Sharon |last2=Mazzetti |first2=Mark |last3=Apuzzo |first3=Matt |date=December 30, 2017 |access-date=December 30, 2017}}</ref>
In July 2016, Page traveled to Moscow for five days,<ref name="Prokop_2/2/2018">{{cite web |last=Prokop |first=Andrew |title=Carter Page, the star of the Nunes memo, explained |website=Vox |date=February 2, 2018 |url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2018/2/2/16956014/nunes-memo-carter-page | access-date=April 13, 2018}}</ref> where he spoke at two meetings on July 7 & 8.<ref>{{Citation |last=Katehon Think Tank |title=The Lecture of Trump's Advisor Carter Page in Moscow |date=July 7, 2016 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1CYF29saA9w |accessdate=May 29, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://apnews.com/7503064184be4df7a5ba021ddc8ea35c/trump-foreign-policy-adviser-has-advice-russian-grads |title=Trump foreign policy adviser has advice for Russian grads |work=Associated Press|access-date=May 29, 2017 |language=en-US}}</ref> Page had received permission from the Trump campaign to make the trip.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2017/03/07/campaign-granted-page-permission-moscow-trip/98874648/ |title=Trump campaign gave Page permission for Moscow trip |work=USA TODAY|access-date=May 29, 2017 |language=en}}</ref> On July 8, Page emailed [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|Trump campaign]] officials about his presentation at the [[New Economic School]] in Moscow and described meeting Russian Deputy Prime Minister [[Arkady Dvorkovich]]. He said Dvorkovich "expressed strong support for Mr. Trump and a desire to work together toward devising better solutions in response to the vast range of current international problems."<ref>{{cite web |title=Russian officials and allies repeatedly signaled support for Trump to his campaign team |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/politics/wp/2017/11/07/russian-officials-and-allies-repeatedly-signaled-support-for-trump-to-his-campaign-team/ |website=[[The Washington Post]] |date=November 7, 2017|access-date=March 26, 2018 |last=Bump |first=Philip}}</ref> Page was later forced, under oath, to reveal he had also met Dvorkovich during the visit.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/carter-page-russia-testimony_us_5a01159be4b066c2c039cb79 |title=In New Testimony, Carter Page Forced To Reveal Meetings With Russian Officials |work=Huffington Post |date=November 11, 2017}}</ref>
The [[Trump–Russia dossier]] alleges that in July, Carter Page secretly met [[Rosneft]] chairman [[Igor Sechin]] in Moscow, together with a "senior Kremlin Internal Affairs official, DIVYEKIN"; that Sechin offered Trump a 19% stake in Rosneft (worth about $11 billion) in exchange for lifting the [[International sanctions during the Ukrainian crisis|sanctions against Russia]] after his election,<ref name="Bertrand_11/6/2017">{{cite web |last=Bertrand |first=Natasha |title=Carter Page's testimony is filled with bombshells - and supports key portions of the Steele dossier |website=[[Business Insider]] |date=November 6, 2017 |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/carter-page-congressional-testimony-transcript-steele-dossier-2017-11 | access-date=December 29, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Weindling_1/11/2017">{{cite web |last=Weindling |first=Jacob |title=The 31 Most Explosive Allegations against Trump from the Leaked Intelligence Document |website=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]] |date=January 11, 2017 |url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2017/01/the-31-most-explosive-allegations-against-trump-fr.html |access-date=December 29, 2017}}</ref> and that Page confirmed, on Trump's "full authority", that he intended to lift the sanctions.<ref name="Withnall_Sengupta_1/12/2017">{{cite web |last=Withnall |first=Adam |last2=Sengupta |first2=Kim |title=The 10 key Donald Trump allegations from the classified Russia memos |website=[[The Independent]] |date=January 12, 2017 |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/donald-trump-russia-10-allegations-dossier-kremlin-michael-cohen-sex-claims-intelligence-reports-a7522056.html | access-date=December 29, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Bertrand_1/27/2017">{{cite web |last=Bertrand |first=Natasha |title=Memos: CEO of Russia's state oil company offered Trump adviser, allies a cut of huge deal if sanctions were lifted |website=[[Business Insider]] |date=January 27, 2017 |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/carter-page-trump-russia-igor-sechin-dossier-2017-1 | access-date=December 29, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Tracy_11/7/2017">{{cite web |last=Tracy |first=Abigail |date=November 7, 2017 |title=Is Carter Page Digging the Trump Administration's Grave? Three things the former campaign adviser revealed to Congress that should scare the White House. |website=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] |url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/11/carter-page-hearing-donald-trump-russia | access-date=December 29, 2017}}</ref>
In September, after reports surfaced about Page's July trip to Russia, the Trump campaign said Page was not part of the campaign and never had been.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/297599-trump-campaign-backs-away-from-adviser-suspected-of-ties-to-kremlin |title=Trump camp backs away from adviser suspected of Kremlin ties |first=Harper |last=Neidig |date=September 24, 2016 |publisher= |accessdate=April 13, 2018}}</ref> Page then said he was taking a leave of absence.
A month later, in October 2016, and after Page left the campaign, the FBI sought a FISA warrant to investigate his connections to Russia.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Prokop |first1=Andrew |title=Carter Page, the star of the Nunes memo, explained |url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2018/2/2/16956014/nunes-memo-carter-page |publisher=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |accessdate=February 4, 2018}}</ref> The warrant was granted by a FISA court judge and has since been renewed thrice, with each 90-day extension requiring new evidence "pertinent to intelligence-related collection" in order to back up the original application and to show that the warrant continues to be productive.<ref name=LaFraniere>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/29/us/politics/release-the-memo-vote-house-intelligence-republicans.html |title=House Republicans Vote to Release Secret Memo on Russia Inquiry |first=Nicholas |last=Fandos |date=February 1, 2018 |newspaper=New York Times}}</ref><ref name=Lucas /><ref name=EmmonsAaronson>{{cite web |last1=Emmons |first1=Alex |last2=Aaronson |first2=Trevor |title=Nunes memo accidentally confirms the legitimacy of the FBI's investigation |url=https://theintercept.com/2018/02/02/nunes-memo-fisa-trump-russia/ |publisher=[[The Intercept]] |accessdate=February 4, 2018}}</ref>
Shortly after the release of the memo, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine reported that in 2013, Carter Page bragged about being an "informal adviser to the Kremlin" in a letter to the editor. Page was asked about this admission on February 6, 2017, on ABC's ''[[Good Morning America]]'' program, and had trouble explaining how he reconciled his dual roles as Trump adviser and Kremlin adviser.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/02/06/politics/carter-page-trump-good-morning-america/index.html |title=Page struggles to explain how he could advise both Kremlin and Trump team |first=Maegan |last=Vazquez |publisher=CNN |accessdate=February 6, 2018}}</ref> Page also claimed that he, despite being named foreign policy adviser, had never actually met Trump, contradicting his earlier statements in which he said he had been in a "number of meetings" with Trump and had "learned a tremendous amount from him".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Nelson |first1=Louis |last2=Griffiths |first2=Brent D. |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/02/05/carter-page-nunes-memo-393054 |title=Carter Page: I've never communicated with Trump |work=Politico |accessdate=February 6, 2018}}</ref>
===Purpose===
Republicans posited that politically-motivated FBI employees attempted to undermine the [[Presidency of Donald Trump|Trump presidency]], citing the [[Trump–Russia dossier]], which they say was an essential part of the evidence used for obtaining a FISA warrant to wiretap Page.<ref name="Kiely_2/27/2018">{{cite web |last=Kiely |first=Eugene |title=Trump's Spin on Democratic Memo |website=FactCheck.org |date=February 27, 2018 |url=https://www.factcheck.org/2018/02/trumps-spin-democratic-memo/ | access-date=March 3, 2018}}</ref><ref name=realaim /> According to this argument, the FBI did not disclose to the FISA court that their request for a warrant depended on evidence in the [[Trump–Russia dossier]], a document funded by the [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016|Hillary Clinton presidential campaign]] and the [[Democratic National Committee]]; according to this line of argument, [[Rod Rosenstein]], Trump's Deputy Attorney General, knew of the funding from Democrats, and his approval of an application that failed to disclose that fact potentially implies that Rosenstein harbors some form of anti-Trump bias.<ref name=EmmonsAaronson/><ref name=Chang>{{cite web |url=https://www.vox.com/2018/2/1/16955472/nunes-memo-release-diagram |title=The Nunes memo, explained with diagrams |publisher=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |date=February 1, 2018 |accessdate=February 1, 2018 |last=Chang |first=Alvin}}</ref> Republicans did eventually concede that the FBI disclosed this information in a footnote.<ref name="footnotePolitico" />
[[Fusion GPS]], the firm behind the document, started its research into Trump with funding from the conservative news outlet ''[[The Washington Free Beacon]]''. However, the news outlet stopped funding this research when Donald Trump received the Republican nomination. Attorney [[Marc Elias]] then hired Fusion GPS on behalf of his clients, the [[Democratic National Committee]] and the [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016|2016 Hillary Clinton presidential campaign]], to continue this research and compile what would become the [[Donald Trump–Russia dossier]].<ref name=WashPo25oct17>{{cite news |last1=Entous |first1=Adam |last2=Barrett |first2=Devlin |last3=Helderman |first3=Rosalind S. |title=Clinton campaign, DNC paid for research that led to Russia dossier |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/clinton-campaign-dnc-paid-for-research-that-led-to-russia-dossier/2017/10/24/226fabf0-b8e4-11e7-a908-a3470754bbb9_story.html |accessdate=October 25, 2017 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=October 25, 2017 |page=A1}}</ref> Fusion GPS paid [[Christopher Steele]] to write the dossier, and the FBI also paid Steele for the expenses<ref name=EmmonsAaronson/> he incurred on "a trip to Rome to meet with FBI officials".<ref name="Robertson_2/7/2018">{{cite web |last=Robertson |first=Lori |title=Q&A on the Nunes Memo |website=FactCheck.org |date=February 7, 2018 |url=https://www.factcheck.org/2018/02/qa-nunes-memo/ | access-date=February 12, 2018}}</ref>
Allies of Trump tried to move focus away from the Trump presidential campaign's alleged role in the Russian election interference by attempting to use the Nunes memo to portray the [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–present)|Special Counsel investigation]] as the real scandal.<ref name=realaim>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/30/us/politics/secret-memo-mueller-russia-investigation.html |title=The Real Aim of the Nunes Memo Is the Mueller Investigation |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=January 30, 2018 |first=Charlie |last=Savage}}</ref> In the hours before the expected release of the memo, sources reported that Trump told his associates that release of the memo would discredit the investigation and give him reason to fire Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, the supervisor of the Special Counsel investigation.<ref name=Liptak>{{cite web |url=http://www.kitv.com/story/37403522/trump-sees-nunes-memo-as-a-way-to-discredit-the-russia-investigation |title=Trump sees Nunes memo as a way to discredit the Russia investigation |publisher=KITV |date=February 1, 2018 |accessdate=February 1, 2018 |last=Liptak |first=Kevin |last2=Collins |first2=Kaitlan}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Rucker |first1=Philip |last2=Parker |first2=Ashley |last3=Dawsey |first3=Josh |title=‘Never any hesitation’: Trump was quickly persuaded to support memo’s release |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/never-any-hesitation-trump-was-quickly-convinced-to-support-memos-release/2018/02/01/b67a0246-076d-11e8-8777-2a059f168dd2_story.html |work=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=February 7, 2018}}</ref>
On February 3, 2018, Trump praised the Nunes memo and tweeted: "This memo totally vindicates 'Trump' in probe. But the Russian Witch Hunt goes on and on. Their [sic] was no Collusion and there was no Obstruction." Rep. [[Trey Gowdy]] (R-S.C.) disagreed, stating on February 4 on CBS’ ''[[Face the Nation]]'': "I actually don't think it has any impact on the Russia probe." He went on to say: {{quote| "There is a Russia investigation without a dossier," Gowdy said. "So to the extent the memo deals with the dossier and the FISA process, the dossier has nothing to do with the meeting at Trump Tower. The dossier has nothing to do with an email sent by Cambridge Analytica. The dossier really has nothing to do with George Papadopoulos' meeting in Great Britain. It also doesn't have anything to do with obstruction of justice. So there's going to be a Russia probe, even without a dossier."<ref name="Robertson_2/7/2018">{{cite web |last=Robertson |first=Lori |title=Q&A on the Nunes Memo |website=FactCheck.org |date=February 7, 2018 |url=https://www.factcheck.org/2018/02/qa-nunes-memo/ | access-date=February 12, 2018}}</ref> }}
Gowdy went on to say he was "100 percent" behind Mueller: "Look, Russia tried to interfere with our election in 2016 with or without a dossier."<ref name="Shafer_2/10/2018">{{cite web |last=Shafer |first=Jack |title=Week 38: Trump Puts the Brakes on the Memo Merry-go-round |website=Politico |date=February 10, 2018 |url=http://politi.co/2H2ec6e | access-date=February 12, 2018}}</ref>
[[Glenn Kessler (journalist)|Glenn Kessler]], a [[fact checker]] for ''[[The Washington Post]]'', analyzed an accusation made by [[Devin Nunes]] in a February 7, 2018, interview on the [[Hugh Hewitt Show]]. Kessler's "[[Pinocchio]] Test" rating was: "{{nowrap|[T]here}} is no evidence that Clinton was involved in Steele's reports or worked with Russian entities to feed information to Steele. That's where Nunes's claim goes off the rails—and why he earns Four Pinocchios."<ref name="Kessler_2/9/2018">{{cite web |last=Kessler |first=Glenn |title=Did Hillary Clinton collude with the Russians to get 'dirt' on Trump to feed it to the FBI? |website=The Washington Post |date=February 9, 2018 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2018/02/09/did-hillary-clinton-collude-with-the-russians-to-get-dirt-on-trump-to-feed-it-to-the-fbi/ | access-date=February 12, 2018}}</ref> According to Kessler "Four Pinocchios" equals a "Whopper" ([[Glenn Kessler (journalist)#''Washington Post'' Fact Checker blog|the equivalent of an outright lie]]).<ref name="Kessler_9/11/2013">{{cite web |last=Kessler |first=Glenn |title=About The Fact Checker |website=Washington Post |date=September 11, 2013 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/about-the-fact-checker/ | access-date=February 13, 2018}}</ref>
==Responses== ===U.S. intelligence community=== {{quote box | quote = As expressed during our initial review, we have grave concerns about material omissions of fact that fundamentally impact the memo's accuracy. | author = The FBI's statement on the Nunes memo | source = CNBC<ref>{{cite web |last1=Javers |first1=Eamon |last2=Breuninger |first2=Kevin |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/01/31/fbi-says-it-has-grave-concerns-about-accuracy-of-house-fisa-memo.html |title=FBI says it has 'grave concerns' about accuracy of hotly debated FISA memo |date=January 31, 2018 |publisher=CNBC |accessdate=February 1, 2018}}</ref> | align = left | width = 30% | quoted = 1 }}
Shortly after becoming a trending topic, the memo drew polarizing reactions from government officials and the media, and generally along [[Partisan (political)|party lines]] for lawmakers.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-russia-memo/justice-department-warned-white-house-about-releasing-memo-washington-post-idUSKBN1FK0AJ |title=Justice Dept warned White House about releasing memo – Washington Post |agency=Reuters |date=January 30, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-01-19/gop-conservatives-brought-russia-probe-demand-to-shutdown-talks |title=Conservatives Brought Russia Probe Demand to Shutdown Talks |date=January 19, 2018 |work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=January 31, 2018 |language=en}}</ref> The [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] (DOJ) released a letter to Congress calling a release of the memo without review "reckless" because it could expose intelligence sources and methods.<ref name="Trump sought release">{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-sought-release-of-classified-russia-memo-putting-him-at-odds-with-justice-department/2018/01/27/a00f2a4c-02bb-11e8-9d31-d72cf78dbeee_story.html |title=Trump sought release of classified Russia memo, putting him at odds with Justice Department |last=Parker |first=Ashley |date=January 27, 2018 |work=Washington Post|access-date=January 29, 2018 |last2=Helderman |first2=Rosalind S. |language=en-US |issn=0190-8286 |last3=Dawsey |first3=Josh |last4=Leonnig |first4=Carol D.}}</ref> FBI Director [[Christopher A. Wray|Christopher Wray]] was allowed to read the memo and did so on January 28. On January 29, the majority of the House Intelligence Committee disregarded the DOJ's warnings and voted to approve the memo's release.<ref name="WaPo2">{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/republicans-vote-to-release-memo-alleging-fbi-missteps-while-surveilling-trump-campaign-operative/2018/01/29/750fb150-0535-11e8-b48c-b07fea957bd5_story.html |title=Republicans vote to release memo alleging FBI missteps while surveilling Trump campaign operative |last=Demirjian |first=Karoun |date=January 29, 2018 |work=Washington Post|access-date=January 29, 2018 |last2=Barrett |first2=Devlin |language=en-US |issn=0190-8286}}</ref> In response, Democrats on the House Intelligence Committee drafted a ten-page rebuttal memo on January 24. Both memos were released to the full House.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Nerb |first1=Jeremy |last2=Raju |first2=Manu |title=Democrats' rebuttal memo criticizes Nunes as part of response |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/01/30/politics/democrats-rebuttal-nunes-memo-criticism/index.html |publisher=CNN |date=January 30, 2018}}</ref> The Republicans voted against making public the competing memo Democrats had crafted, and rejected a proposal to give the Justice Department and FBI more time to vet the document. The President then had up to five days to review it before it could be officially released.<ref>{{Cite news |author=Kyle Cheney |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/01/29/trey-gowdy-devin-nunes-fbi-classified-memo-374688 |title=House panel votes to release secret memo |work=Politico |date=January 29, 2018}}</ref>
Republicans sought a committee vote that would request the release through the President, which would keep the memo confined to committee members until the President responded.<ref name="cnn1" /> The memo could be made public by a vote in the House of Representatives if the President did not act or denied the request, but no vote was scheduled for the full House.<ref name="vice">{{cite web |last=Liautaud |first=Alexa |url=https://news.vice.com/en_us/article/paq5wm/these-two-deep-state-conspiracy-theories-are-driving-republicans-nuts-today |title=These two deep-state conspiracy theories are driving Republicans nuts today |publisher=Vice News |date=January 25, 2018 |accessdate=January 29, 2018}}</ref>
Nunes and the House Intelligence Committee denied access to the memo by the Senate Intelligence Committee and the FBI, which expressed a desire to investigate any alleged wrongdoing.<ref name="cnn1">{{Cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/01/24/politics/richard-burr-devin-nunes-fisa-memo/index.html |title=Senate panel denied access to Nunes FISA memo |authors=Jeremy Herb and Manu Raju |publisher=CNN|access-date=January 25, 2018}}</ref> The Department of Justice sent a letter to Nunes and called the release of the memo "extraordinarily reckless."<ref name="Jarrett">{{Cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/01/24/politics/nunes-memo-fbi/index.html |title=Justice Dept.: 'Reckless' to release Nunes memo without review |last=Jarrett |first=Laura |publisher=CNN |date=January 24, 2018}}</ref> Nunes' panel refused to allow the FBI and the Justice Department to view the memo despite their requests.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thehill.com/policy/national-security/370984-what-you-need-to-know-about-the-house-intel-memo |title=The classified Intel memo: What you need to know |first=Olivia |last=Beavers |date=January 26, 2018 |work=The Hill |accessdate=February 1, 2018}}</ref>
[[Adam Schiff]], ranking member of the House Intelligence Committee, issued a statement saying it was "[r]ife with factual inaccuracies" and was "meant only to give Republican House members a distorted view of the FBI."<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/republicans-call-for-release-of-memo-on-surveillance-abuses/ |title=Republicans call for release of memo on alleged surveillance abuses |publisher=CBS News |date=January 19, 2018}}</ref> Schiff also said the memo omits key information on evidence other than Steele's dossier, used in the application for the FISA warrant.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/29/us/politics/fisa-surveillance-applications-how-they-work.html |title=How to Get a Wiretap to Spy on Americans, and Why That Matters Now |first=Charlie |last=Savage |date=February 1, 2018 |newspaper=New York Times}}</ref>
On July 21, 2018, the Justice Department released a heavily redacted version of the October 2016 [[FISA]] warrant application for Carter Page, which stated in part "The FBI believes that Page has been collaborating and conspiring with the Russian government" and "the FBI believes that the Russian government's efforts are being coordinated with Page and perhaps other individuals associated with Candidate #1's campaign."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/21/us/politics/carter-page-fisa.html |title=Justice Dept. Releases Secret Carter Page Surveillance Documents at Center of Partisan Clash|publisher=|accessdate=July 21, 2018}}</ref>
===Trump administration=== On January 24, 2018, Trump expressed support for releasing the Nunes memo. He reportedly told close advisers that he believed the memo would reveal the FBI's bias against him, and provide grounds for him to fire [[Rod Rosenstein]].<ref name="Trump sought release" /> [[White House Counsel]] [[Don McGahn]] wrote that "the memorandum reflects the judgments of its congressional authors" and that the reason for its release was "significant public interest in the memorandum."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Blake |first1=Aaron |title=Analysis: The full Nunes memo, annotated |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2018/02/02/the-full-nunes-memo-annotated/ |work=Washington Post |date=February 2, 2018}}</ref> After its release, Trump claimed in a tweet that the memo "totally vindicates" him.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Cochrane |first1=Emily |title=Trump Says Republican Memo ‘Totally Vindicates' Him |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/03/us/politics/trump-memo-vindicates.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=February 4, 2018}}</ref>
===Republicans=== Before the memo was released, House Speaker [[Paul Ryan]] warned his fellow Republicans against overplaying the contents of the memo and tying it to the Mueller investigation.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Williams |first1=Katie Bo |last2=Wong |first2=Scott |url=http://thehill.com/policy/national-security/371397-ryan-urges-lawmakers-dont-overplay-memo |title=Ryan urges lawmakers: Don't overplay memo |date=January 30, 2018 |work=The Hill |accessdate=February 4, 2018}}</ref> After the memo was released, Ryan said, "The matter of concern outlined in this memo is a specific, legitimate one. Our FISA system is critical to keeping America safe from real and evolving threats. It is a unique system with broad discretion and a real impact on Americans' civil liberties."<ref>{{cite news |last=Weaver |first=Al |url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/paul-ryan-nunes-memo-lays-out-a-specific-legitimate-worry-about-surveillance/article/2647957 |title=Paul Ryan: Nunes memo lays out a 'specific, legitimate' worry about surveillance |work=Washington Examiner |date=February 2, 2018 |accessdate=February 4, 2018}}</ref> Ryan also supported the release of the Democrats' counter-memo.<ref>{{cite web |last=Manchester |first=Julia |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/house/371974-paul-ryan-supports-release-of-democrats-memo-spox |title=Ryan supports release of Democrats' countermemo |date=February 2, 2018 |work=The Hill |accessdate=February 4, 2018}}</ref>
Representative [[Trey Gowdy]], the only Republican on the House Intelligence Committee who actually read the underlying classified material, said the FISA application cited other material besides the dossier, but in his opinion the warrant would not have been authorized without the dossier. He added that the dossier does not invalidate the Russia investigation, which would have been launched with or without it. He said he has confidence in Rosenstein, Wray, and Mueller.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Watson |first1=Kathryn |title=Gowdy says surveillance warrant would not have been authorized without dossier |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trey-gowdy-face-the-nation-fisa-surveillance-warrant-would-not-have-been-authorized-without-dossier/ |agency=CBS News |date=February 4, 2018}}</ref>
On February 2, [[John McCain]] rebuked his fellow Republicans with the statement, "The latest attacks against the FBI and Department of Justice serve no American interests―no party's, no president's, only [[Vladimir Putin|Putin's]]. ... If we continue to undermine our own rule of law, we are doing Putin's job for him."<ref name="Murdock_2/2/2018">{{cite news |last1=Murdock |first1=Sebastian |title=Sen. John McCain On Nunes Memo Release: ‘We Are Doing Putin’s Job For Him’ |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/sen-john-mccain-nunes-memo-putin_us_5a749987e4b06ee97af24494 |accessdate=February 3, 2018 |work=Huffington Post |date=February 2, 2018}}</ref>
===Democrats=== [[File:Correcting the Record - The Russia Investigations.pdf|thumb|Democrats' rebuttal memo]] Democratic leaders in Congress—[[House Minority Leader]] [[Nancy Pelosi]] and [[Senate Minority Leader]] [[Chuck Schumer]]—called upon House Speaker [[Paul Ryan]] to remove Nunes from the House Intelligence Committee, accusing him of abusing his position as committee chairman and of working in coordination with the White House that the committee is supposed to be investigating.<ref name="NBC 02012018">{{cite news |last1=Clark |first1=Dartunorro |title=Schumer, Pelosi call for Nunes to be removed as House intelligence chair |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/schumer-pelosi-call-nunes-be-removed-house-intelligence-chair-n843706 |accessdate=February 4, 2018 |work=NBC News |date=February 1, 2018}}</ref> Pelosi referred to the document as a "bogus" memo which was part of a Republican cover-up campaign; she also said Nunes had disgraced the House committee. Schumer said that the memo aimed to spread "conspiracy theories" and attacked federal law enforcement in order to protect Trump from investigation.<ref name="NBC 02012018" /> Democratic House Whip [[Steny Hoyer]] also called for Nunes to be removed, saying Nunes' behavior had undermined the American people's trust in his chairmanship of the committee.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Manchester |first1=Julia |title=Hoyer calls on Ryan to remove Nunes after release of memo |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/house/372052-hoyer-calls-on-ryan-to-remove-nunes-after-release-of-memo |accessdate=February 4, 2018 |work=The Hill |date=February 2, 2018}}</ref>
[[Jerry Nadler]] of New York, the [[ranking member]] of the [[House Judiciary Committee]], issued a six-page analysis rebutting the memo's legal basis and accusing Republican House members of being part of "an organized effort to obstruct" Mueller's investigation. Nadler, who reviewed the classified material used to obtain the FISA warrant, called the memo "deliberately misleading and deeply wrong on the law." He argued the FISA Court had probable cause to believe Page was acting as "an [[Foreign agent|agent of a foreign power]]."<ref name="Memoli">{{cite web |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/democratic-rebuttal-calls-nunes-memo-deliberately-misleading-n844426 |title=Democratic rebuttal calls Nunes memo 'deliberately misleading' |publisher=[[CBS News]] |date=February 3, 2018 |accessdate=February 4, 2018 |last=Memoli |first=Mike}}</ref><ref name="Stracqualursi">{{cite web |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/02/03/politics/nadler-democratic-rebuttal-nunes-memo/index.html |title=Judiciary Democrat's rebuttal to Nunes memo accuses House GOP of obstructing Russia probe |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=February 4, 2018 |accessdate=February 4, 2018 |last=Stracqualursi |first=Veronica}}</ref>
[[Adam Schiff]] has stated that the "Nunes memo is designed to...["put the government on trial"] by furthering a conspiracy theory that a cabal of senior officials within the FBI and the Justice Department were so tainted by bias against President Donald Trump that they irredeemably poisoned the investigation."<ref name="Schiff_2/1/2018">{{cite web |last=Schiff |first=Adam |title=The Nunes memo crosses a dangerous line |website=Chicago Tribune |date=February 1, 2018 |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/opinion/commentary/ct-devin-nunes-memo-fbi-20180201-story.html | access-date=February 28, 2018}}</ref>
==== Rebuttal memo ==== {{Wikisource|Correcting the Record – The Russia Investigations}}
Democrats on the House Intelligence Committee drafted a classified ten-page rebuttal memo on January 24.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/house-democrats-plan-memo-to-counter-gops-as-calls-to-declassify-files-grow/2018/01/24/3161b48c-0146-11e8-bb03-722769454f82_story.html |title=House Democrats plan memo to counter GOP’s, as calls to declassify files grow |last=Demirjian |first=Karoun |date=January 24, 2018 |work=Washington Post|access-date=January 25, 2018 |language=en-US |issn=0190-8286}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2018-01-25/russian-bots-are-right-releasethememo |title=Russian Bots Are Right: #Releasethememo |author=Eli Lake |date=January 25, 2018 |website=[[Bloomberg.com]]|access-date=January 26, 2018}}</ref> However, when the committee voted along partisan lines to release the Nunes memo, it also voted not to release the Democratic memo.<ref name="WaPo2" /> On February 5 the committee voted unanimously to release the Democrat’s minority memo, subject to Trump's approval.<ref name=":0" /> On February 9, Trump declined to release the rebuttal memo, with the White House suggesting sensitive sections be removed before the memo is made public.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> McGahn stated this was because of its "numerous properly classified and especially sensitive passages."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.politico.eu/article/trump-russia-probe-blocks-release-of-democratic-memo/ |title=Trump blocks release of Democratic Russia memo |last=Guardia |first=Arnau Busquets |date=February 10, 2018 |work=Politico |accessdate=February 10, 2018}}</ref> After redactions in consultation with the FBI, the Democratic memo, titled ''Correcting the Record -- The Russia Investigation'', was released on February 24.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-02-24/public-release-of-democratic-rebuttal-memo-could-be-imminent |title=Democrats’ Memo Released Countering GOP Account of Russia Probe |last=House |first=Billy |date=February 24, 2018 |work=Bloomberg News |accessdate=February 25, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Prokop_2/24/2018">{{cite web |last=Prokop |first=Andrew |title=Read: Democrats’ response to the Nunes memo was just released |website=Vox |date=February 24, 2018 |url=https://www.vox.com/2018/2/24/17048764/schiff-memo-nunes-read | access-date=February 24, 2018 |quote=Here’s the full text of the Schiff memo .. Democrats on the committee led by Rep. Adam Schiff (D-CA) accused the memo of being misleading, and put together their own memo in response.}}</ref> This rebuttal memo has also been referred to as the Schiff memo after [[Adam Schiff]].<ref name="Prokop_2/24/2018"/>
===Criticism=== Revelations about the Nunes memo and its surrounding controversy, including speculation about the potential firing of Mueller or [[United States Deputy Attorney General|Deputy Attorney General]] Rod Rosenstein, gave rise to comparisons to the [[Saturday night massacre]], alluding to the firing of special prosecutor [[Archibald Cox]] by President [[Richard Nixon]] during the [[Watergate scandal]].<ref name=Eisen>{{cite web |url=https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2018/01/31/trumps-saturday-night-massacre-is-happening-right-before-our-eyes-216560 |title=Trump’s Saturday Night Massacre Is Happening Right Before Our Eyes |publisher=[[Politico]] |date=January 31, 2018 |accessdate=February 2, 2018 |last=Eisen |first=Norman |last2=Fredickson |first2=Caroline |last3=Bookbinder |first3=Noah}}</ref><ref name=Shalev>{{cite web |url=https://www.haaretz.com/us-news/when-trump-fires-mueller-watergate-could-seem-like-child-s-play-1.5785790 |title=When Trump Fires Mueller, Watergate Could Seem Like Child's Play |publisher=[[Haaretz]] |date=February 2, 2018 |accessdate=February 2, 2018 |last=Shalev |first=Chemi}}</ref><ref name=DavidSmith>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/02/trump-nunes-memo-republicans-nixon |title=Trump's release of Nunes memo is Nixonian – but today's GOP won't resist |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |date=February 2, 2018 |accessdate=February 2, 2018 |last=Smith |first=David}}</ref><ref name=Dartunorro>{{cite web |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/democrats-condemn-release-nunes-memo-n844146 |title=Democrats, some GOP lawmakers criticize release of Nunes memo |publisher=[[NBC News]] |date=February 2, 2018 |accessdate=February 2, 2018 |last=Clark |first=Dartunorro}}</ref>
[[Glenn Greenwald]] called the Republican-led campaign to release the memo "a bizarre spectacle" since the Republicans were "holding a document that only they can release, while pretending to be advocating for its release."<ref name=vice/>
In response to the release of Nunes's document, former FBI director [[James Comey]] wrote, "That's it? Dishonest and misleading memo wrecked the House intel committee, destroyed trust with Intelligence Community, damaged relationship with FISA court, and inexcusably exposed classified investigation of an American citizen. For what?"<ref>{{cite news |first=Mary |last=Papenfuss |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/james-comey-memo-response_us_5a74e663e4b0905433b42efc |title=An Angry James Comey On The GOP Memo: ‘That’s It?’ |work=HuffPost |date=February 2, 2018}}</ref>
In an interview on ''[[Meet the Press]]'', former [[director of the Central Intelligence Agency|CIA director]] [[John O. Brennan]] said that Nunes had presented only "one side, in a very selective, cherry-picked memo." He said that for Nunes and the Republicans to deny the Democratic minority the ability to release their own memo "is just appalling, and it clearly underscores just how partisan Mr. Nunes has been." Brennan accused Nunes of an [[abuse of power]] in the use of his position on the House Intelligence Committee. "I don't say that lightly," he added.<ref>Shane Harris, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nunesabused-his-power-on-intelligence-committee-former-cia-director-says/2018/02/04/59ff42c0-09c4-11e8-baf5-e629fc1cd21e_story.html Nunes 'abused' his power on intelligence committee, former CIA director says], ''Washington Post'' (February 4, 2018).</ref>
Three former CIA analysts (Jeff Asher, Nada Bakos and Cindy Otis) wrote that the "politically motivated, recklessly drafted" Nunes memo "does not support its main thesis" alleging abuse by the FBI and Department of Justice regarding their investigation of Carter Page as it "doesn't offer any evidence of the potential abuse and, in fact, the memo undermines itself".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Asher |first1=Jeff |last2=Bakos |first2=Nada |last3=Otis |first3=Cindy |title=Former CIA analysts: We can't trust Devin Nunes |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/02/07/opinions/nunes-memo-opinion-asher-bakos-otis/index.html |publisher=[[CNN]] |accessdate=February 8, 2018}}</ref>
Senator [[Sheldon Whitehouse]] has accused the authors of the memo of "using selective declassification as a tactic—they use declassified information to tell their side, and then the rebuttal is classified." [[Jane Mayer]] stated that this leaves [[Christopher Steele]]'s defenders no possibility "to respond without breaching national-security secrets".<ref name="Mayer_3/12/2018">{{cite web |last=Mayer |first=Jane |title=Christopher Steele, the Man Behind the Trump Dossier |website=The New Yorker |date=March 12, 2018 |url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2018/03/12/christopher-steele-the-man-behind-the-trump-dossier | access-date=March 6, 2018}}</ref>
Paul Rosensweig, former [[Assistant Secretary for International Affairs]] and former [[Whitewater controversy|Whitewater]] investigator, has analyzed the Nunes memo and explained several reasons for why he believes "it makes no sense", is "not a serious effort at oversight", and "fails to make its case": the timing of the FISA warrant shows that any findings would first have come to light after the election and thus could not have affected it; Carter Page was no longer a member of the Trump campaign at the time of the application; it ignores that Page was under FISA surveillance as early as 2013 because of his proven Russian connections; the attempt to tie the October FISA application to Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein is flawed because Rosenstein was a U.S. attorney for the district of Maryland at the time and had nothing to do with that application; the memo "uses language that is intended to create a misimpression" by implying that the [[Trump–Russia dossier]] was central to the FISA application, when it was only a part of it; and that the memo "tries to bury" its "admission deep in the document", in the final paragraph, that the investigation into [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]] was not triggered by the Steele dossier but by information from Trump advisor Papadopoulos.<ref name="Rosenzweig_2/2/2018">{{cite web | last=Rosenzweig | first=Paul | title=Even If You Take the Nunes Memo Seriously, It Makes No Sense | website=[[Politico]] | date=February 2, 2018 | url=https://www.politico.com/magazine/amp/story/2018/02/02/the-nunes-memo-makes-no-sense-216928 | access-date=May 9, 2018}}</ref>
==Release of Carter Page FISA warrant applications== [[File:Optimized.pdf|thumb|Carter Page FISA warrant applications]]
On July 21, 2018, the Justice Department released heavily redacted versions of four FISA warrant applications for Carter Page which showed that key assertions made in the Nunes memo were false or misleading, corroborating the rebuttal made by Democrats.<ref name="Savage">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/22/us/politics/how-a-trump-decision-revealed-a-gop-memos-shaky-foundation.html|title=How a Trump Decision Revealed a G.O.P. Memo’s Shaky Foundation|publisher=|accessdate=July 25, 2018}}</ref> The Nunes memo:
* Contended the application did not "disclose or reference the role of the DNC, Clinton campaign or any party/campaign in funding Steele’s efforts, even though the political origins of the Steele dossier were then known to senior DOJ and FBI officials,” an assertion Democrats disputed in their rebuttal. The application provided a page-length explanation that the person who commissioned Steele was “likely looking for information to discredit” the Trump campaign. The application also explained that, despite the political motives of those who commissioned Steele, the FBI found Steele credible.<ref name="auto1"/><ref name="Savage"/>
* Faulted the application for not identifying Hillary Clinton or the DNC by name. However, the application showed the standard practice of omitting the names of American individuals and organizations. For example, Trump and Clinton were identified only as "Candidate #1" and "Candidate #2," respectively.<ref name="Savage"/>
* Asserted the DOJ referenced a ''Yahoo News'' article as corroboration of Steele's information, even though it later became known that Steele had been a source for the article, an assertion rebutted by Democrats. However, the application actually cited the ''Yahoo News'' article only to show that Carter Page had denied allegations against him, under a section entitled "Page’s Denial of Cooperation With the Russian Government."<ref name="Savage"/>
Multiple sources also noted that after its publication, the wiretap warrant was approved, and later renewed, four times by four different judges, all of whom were appointed by Republican presidents.<ref name="Savage"/><ref>{{citation|title=Trump Administration Releases Classified Warrants For FBI Wiretap Of Carter Page|author=Daniella Cheslow|publisher=National Public Radio|date=July 22, 2018|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/07/22/631260082/trump-administration-releases-classified-warrants-for-fbi-wiretap-of-carter-page}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first1=Chas|last1=Danner|accessdate=2018-07-25|title=Newly Disclosed FISA Applications Disprove ‘Witch Hunt’ Claims From Trump, Nunes|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2018/07/fisa-documents-dispel-witch-hunt-claims-from-trump-nunes.html|newspaper=Daily Intelligencer}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=https://www.ft.com/content/d9000216-8dc8-11e8-b639-7680cedcc421|title=Trump attacks ‘illegal’ surveillance of campaign aide|publisher=Financial Times|date=July 22, 2018}}</ref> Similarly, all four judges — [[Rosemary M. Collyer|Rosemary Collyer]], [[Anne C. Conway|Anne Conway]], [[Raymond J. Dearie| Raymond Dearie]] and [[Michael W. Mosman|Michael Mosman]] — were assigned to serve on the FISA court by Chief Justice [[John Roberts]], a conservative.<ref name="lawandcrime.com">{{cite web|url=https://lawandcrime.com/politics/judges-who-approved-carter-page-fisa-warrants-were-all-nominated-by-gop-presidents/|title=Judges Who Approved Carter Page FISA Warrants Were All Nominated by GOP Presidents|website=lawandcrime.com|accessdate=August 14, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/12/opinion/kavanaugh-supreme-court-right.html|title=Opinion - The Chart That Shows the Supreme Court Will Be Out of Step With the Country|publisher=|accessdate=August 14, 2018}}</ref>
The day after the applications were released, Trump asserted without evidence that they confirmed the Justice Department and FBI had misled the FISA court and as a result his campaign had been illegally spied on to benefit the Clinton campaign. Trump also quoted conservative writer [[Andrew C. McCarthy|Andrew McCarthy]], who had called into question the integrity of the FISA court itself.<ref name="lawandcrime.com"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/22/us/politics/trump-fisa-carter-page.html|title=Without Evidence, Trump Claims Vindication From Release of Carter Page Documents|publisher=|accessdate=July 26, 2018}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Dismissal of James Comey]] *[[Links between Trump associates and Russian officials]] *[[Trump Tower wiretapping allegations]]

revision.text:
{{Lowercase|rPerf}} '''rPerf''' is a [[computer benchmark]] that evaluates the relative [[OLTP]] performance of servers based on [[IBM POWER microprocessors]]. It is published by [[IBM]] and derived from a model based on specific workloads, plus benchmarks from [[Transaction Processing Performance Council]] and [[SPEC]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ibmsystemsmag.com/aix/administrator/performance/Its-All-Relative/ |title=It's All Relative |publisher=IBMSystems Magazine |accessdate=2011-08-03}}</ref>
==References== <references />
