{{Infobox Museum |name = Sukkulenten-Sammlung Zürich |image = File:Mythenquai - Sukkulentensammlung 2015-02-26 11-48-05.JPG |caption = Main entrance |location = [[Mythenquai]], Enge, Zürich |publictransit = '''[[Verkehrsbetriebe Zürich]]:''' Bus line 161 and 165 stop ''Mythenquai''
'''[[S-Bahn Zürich]]:''' S-Bahn line [[S8 (ZVV)|S8]] stop ''Enge'' or ''[[Wollishofen]]'' |coordinates = {{coord|47|21|21.93|N|8|32|6.35|E|display=inline,title}} |established = {{Start date|1931}} |website = {{URL|https://www.stadt-zuerich.ch/ted/de/index/gsz/natur-_und_erlebnisraeume/sukkulenten-sammlung.html|sukkulentensammlung.ch}} |owner = Stadt Zürich }} [[File:Sukkulentensammlung - Innenansicht 2015-01-05 15-49-37 (P7800).JPG|thumb|upright|Interior at the entrance area]] [[File:Sukkulentensammlung - Innenansicht 2015-01-05 15-46-48 (P7800).JPG|thumb|upright]] [[File:Sukkulentensammlung - Innenansicht 2015-01-05 15-47-21 (P7800).JPG|thumb|upright]] [[File:Sukkulentensammlung - Innenansicht 2015-01-05 15-45-55 (P7800).JPG|thumb|upright|''Haworthia viscosa'']] '''Sukkulenten-Sammlung Zürich''', literally [[succulent plant]] collection of the city of [[Zürich]], is a botanical garden in the [[Switzerland|Swiss]] [[Municipalities of the canton of Zürich|municipality]] of Zürich. It also houses a botanic library, a herbarium and the [[International Organizations for Succulent Plant Research]] (IOS).{{cite web|url=http://www.iosweb.org/|title=IOS|publisher=Grün Stadt Zürich|author=|language=|date=|accessdate=2015-01-02|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150103014935/http://www.iosweb.org/|archivedate=2015-01-03|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.stadt-zuerich.ch/ted/de/index/gsz/natur-_und_erlebnisraeume/sukkulenten-sammlung/weltweite_vernetzung.html|title=Weltweite Vernetzung|publisher=Grün Stadt Zürich|author=|language=German|date=|accessdate=2015-01-02|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150103014831/https://www.stadt-zuerich.ch/ted/de/index/gsz/natur-_und_erlebnisraeume/sukkulenten-sammlung/weltweite_vernetzung.html|archivedate=2015-01-03|df=}} == Location == The greenhouses are located in district of [[Enge (Zürich)|Enge]], on [[Zürichsee]] (Lake Zurich). They are a part of the [[Quaianlagen (Zürich)|Quaianlagen]] promenades, and are located on the southwestern lake shore. The collection is separated by the [[Mythenquai]] road from the lower lake shore promenade and the Enge harbour area, at the park facilities of the [[Strandbad Mythenquai|Mythenquai lido]] near the lower entrance to the [[Rieterpark]]. == History == At the end of the 1920s, Jakob Gasser, a cactus grower from Zürich, tried to sell his collection of about 1,500 succulents to the city government of Zürich, but the venture failed. in 1929, Julius Brann Gassersche, a store owner, acquired the unique collection and made a gift of it to the city of Zürich. The collection was housed in the greenhouses at the former site of the municipal gardens (''Stadtgärtnerei'') at Mythenquai, and established as ''Städtische Kakteensammlung'', meaning urban cactus collection.{{cite web|url=https://www.stadt-zuerich.ch/ted/de/index/gsz/natur-_und_erlebnisraeume/park-_und_gruenanlagen/arboretum.html|title=Sukkulentensammlung|publisher=Grün Stadt Zürich, [[Arboretum Zürich]]|author=|language=German|date=|accessdate=2015-01-02|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141228185059/https://www.stadt-zuerich.ch/ted/de/index/gsz/natur-_und_erlebnisraeume/park-_und_gruenanlagen/arboretum.html|archivedate=2014-12-28|df=}} Formally established in 1931, the collection houses one of the largest and most important collections of succulent plants.{{cite web|url=https://www.stadt-zuerich.ch/content/dam/stzh/ted/Deutsch/gsz/Natur-%20und%20Erlebnisraeume/Publikationen%20und%20Broschueren/Sukkulenten-Sammlung/Vom%20Buerkliplatz%20zur%20Sukkulenten-Sammlung1.pdf|title=Vom Bürkliplatz zur Sukkulenten-Sammlung|publisher=[[Grün Stadt Zürich]]|author=Grün Stadt Zürich|language=German|date=May 2006|accessdate=2015-01-02|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305075257/https://www.stadt-zuerich.ch/content/dam/stzh/ted/Deutsch/gsz/Natur-%20und%20Erlebnisraeume/Publikationen%20und%20Broschueren/Sukkulenten-Sammlung/Vom%20Buerkliplatz%20zur%20Sukkulenten-Sammlung1.pdf|archivedate=2016-03-05|df=}} The main complex was built in 1947 and inaugurated in 1948. The succulent collection started in the existing greenhouse at Mythenquai, and was extended in 1948, 1954, 1961, 1984. In 2011, the entrance area was rebuilt and information for visitors improved. There are plans to redesign the Mythenquai area, including a renovation of the greenhouses.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} == Collection and structure == Succulents are plants from arid areas that survive by storing water, including [[Agave]]s, [[Aloe]]s and stonecrop family, in addition to [[Cactus|Cacti]] and thick leaf plants. The collection features more than 6,500 different types of succulent plants from more than 80 different plant families of ''[[Orchidaceae]]'', ''[[Crassulaceae]]'', ''[[Euphorbiaceae]]'', ''[[Aizoaceae]]'', ''[[Cactaceae]]'' and ''[[Apocynaceae]]''. The collection is funded by [[Grün Stadt Zürich]] and by the booster association, ''Förderverein der Sukkulenten-Sammlung Zürich''.{{cite web|url=http://www.foerderverein.ch/|title=Förderverein der Sukkulenten-Sammlung Zürich|publisher=foerderverein.ch/|author=|language=German|date=|accessdate=2015-01-02|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150102212143/http://www.foerderverein.ch/|archivedate=2015-01-02|df=}} Although internationally known for its scientific objectives, the Sukkulenten-Sammlung is perceived by the public as a collection. Periodic special displays provide an insight into the survival mechanisms used by succulents. == Facilities == Surrounded by a park on the lake, the facilities house over 25,000 exotic plants in about 6,500 species and varieties on {{convert|4750|sqm|acre|2}}, including {{convert|700|sqm|acre|2}} in six greenhouses, 16 heated cold frame boxes and an outdoor area. The staff consists of nine employees who take care of to 50,000 visitors annually. The greenhouses are open daily. == IOS library, database and herbarium == Since about 1947, the institution has been involved in an international seed exchange between botanical institutes and gardens around the world. Currently, there are more than 200 botanical gardens involved. In addition, Sukkulenten-Sammlung houses a specialized library on succulent plants. These books are not allowed to leave the library, but can be seen when the collection is open. The library contains more than 30,187 titles. The [[herbarium]] was founded in 1950, simultaneously with the [[International Organizations for Succulent Plant Research]] (IOS), and has an extensive archive of plants with approximately 20,000 specimens and a meticulous tracking database. It is now under the patronage of the Swiss [[UNESCO]] commission. == Förderverein association == Despite the uniqueness of the collection, in 1996 the municipal council (''Gemeinderat'') of the city of Zürich sought to either outsource the collection of succulents or to close the collection entirely. This political pressure led to the founding of the boosting association ''Förderverein der Sukkulenten-Sammlung Zürich''. The council then decided to suspend the motion, until it became clear whether the [[Canton of Zürich]] and the federal authorities would become involved in co-financing. == Cultural heritage of national importance == Sukkulenten-Sammlung Zürich is listed in the [[Swiss inventory of cultural property of national and regional significance]] as a ''Class A'' object of national importance.{{cite web|url=http://www.bevoelkerungsschutz.admin.ch/internet/bs/de/home/themen/kgs/kgs_inventar/a-objekte.parsys.000108.DownloadFile.tmp/zh2015.pdf|title=A-Objekte KGS-Inventar|publisher=Schweizerische Eidgenossenschaft, Amt für Bevölkerungsschutz|author=|language=|date=2015-01-01|accessdate=2015-09-13|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001193946/http://www.bevoelkerungsschutz.admin.ch/internet/bs/de/home/themen/kgs/kgs_inventar/a-objekte.parsys.000108.DownloadFile.tmp/zh2015.pdf|archivedate=2015-10-01|df=}} == Literature == * ''Gartenbiografien: Orte erzählen''. vdf Hochschulverlag AG, ETH Zürich, Zürich 2013, {{ISBN|978-3-7281-3579-7}}. == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == {{commons category|Sukkulenten-Sammlung Zürich}} * {{Official website|https://www.stadt-zuerich.ch/ted/de/index/gsz/natur-_und_erlebnisraeume/sukkulenten-sammlung.html|name='''Sukkulenten-Sammlung Zürich''' website}} {{de icon}} * [http://www.foerderverein.ch/ Förderverein] {{de icon}} * [http://www.iosweb.org/ IOSweb.org: International Organizations for Succulent Plant Research website] {{Parks in Zürich}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sukkulenten-Sammlung Zurich}} [[Category:Botanical gardens in Switzerland]] [[Category:Museums in Zürich]] [[Category:Parks in Zürich]] [[Category:Succulent plants]] [[Category:Agricultural buildings in Switzerland]] [[Category:Botanical research institutes]] [[Category:Greenhouses]] [[Category:Herbaria]] [[Category:Libraries in Zürich]] [[Category:Science libraries]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Zürich]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1931]] [[Category:1931 establishments in Switzerland]] [[Category:Organisations based in Zürich]] [[Category:Scientific organizations established in 1950]] [[Category:1950 establishments in Switzerland]] [[Category:Cultural property of national significance in the canton of Zürich]] [[Category:District 2 of Zürich]]

{{italic title}} '''''The Jepson Manual''''' is a [[Flora (publication)|flora]] of the vascular plants that are either [[List of California native plants|native]] to or naturalized in [[California]]. [[Botanist]]s often refer to the book simply as '''''Jepson'''''. It is produced by the [[University and Jepson Herbaria]], of the [[University of California, Berkeley]].<ref>[http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu University & Jepson Herbaria]</ref>
==History== *1923: Willis Linn Jepson — ''Manual of the Flowering Plants of California'' *1958, 1968: Phillip Munz — ''A California Flora and Supplement'' *1993: J.C. Hickman (editor) — ''The Jepson Manual, Higher Plants of California'' (TJM93) *2012: Bruce Baldwin — ''The Jepson Manual: Vascular Plants of California, 2nd edition'' (TJM2) *2010−ongoing: [[Jepson Manual Online|The Jepson Online Interchange for California Floristics − Jepson eFlora]] (TJM2) — ''online''.
===Preceding works=== ''The Jepson Manual'' is considered a revision of the first major California flora publication, the ''Manual of the Flowering Plants of California'' by [[Willis Linn Jepson]]. It was originally published in 1925.
''The Jepson Manual'' also follows [[Philip A. Munz]] and [[David D. Keck]] in their ''A California Flora and Supplement'' of 1958 and 1968.<ref>"''The Jepson Manual: Higher Plants of California''" by James C. Hickman, Rudolf Schmid, ''Taxon'', Vol. 42, No. 2 (May, 1993), pp. 508-510</ref>
Like other florae, ''The Jepson Manual'' builds upon these prior publications. Except for the number of line drawings, it has more in common with Munz's 1968 book than with Jepson's 1923 book. <!---visual comparison---{{Fact|date=June 2008}}--?-->
===Editions=== The first edition of ''The Jepson Manual'' was published in 1993 as '''''The Jepson Manual: Higher Plants of California''''' (TJM93), and was edited by James C. Hickman.<ref>[http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/jepman.html Ucjeps.berkeley.edu: The Jepson Manual]</ref>
The second edition was published in 2012, as ''The Jepson Manual: Vascular Plants of California, Thoroughly Revised and Expanded'' (TJM2), and was edited by [[Bruce G. Baldwin]], Douglas Goldman, David J Keil, Robert Patterson, and Thomas J. Rosatti. The second edition features 7,601 California plant species, subspecies and varieties.<ref>[http://newscenter.berkeley.edu/2012/01/30/california-native-plant-classic-jepson-manual-revision/ UC Berkeley News Center: "California native-plant classic gets a 21st-century makeover"], by Cathy Cockrell</ref> <ref>[http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/new_era.html Ucjeps.berkeley.edu: Second Edition of The Jepson Manual update]</ref>
While the book is named in honor of Jepson, ''The Jepson Manual'' is not simply a new edition of Jepson's 1923 book, but a new work which Baldwin calls "“the most time-consuming undertaking of my career."<ref>"California native-plant classic gets a 21st-century makeover"</ref>
==See also== *[[Jepson Manual Online|''Jepson Manual'' Online]] *{{C|Flora of California|Flora of California-related topics}} *[[List of California native plants]] *[[University and Jepson Herbaria]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/interchange/ The Jepson Online Interchange for California Floristics − Jepson eFlora] — ''online search engine for taxonomic treatments''. * [http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/IJM.html Jepson eFlora Homepage] * [http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu University & Jepson Herbaria Home Page] * [http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/images/fieldbooks/jepson_fieldbooks.html Field Books of Willis Linn Jepson]

revision.text:
{{Infobox book |name=Tongzhi |author=Zheng Qiao |country=[[Song dynasty]] |language=[[Classical Chinese]] |subject=[[general knowledge]] |pub_date=1161 }} {{chinese|c={{linktext|通|志}}|w=T'ung-chih|p=Tōngzhì}} '''''Tongzhi''''' ("Comprehensive Records") is a 1161 Chinese [[general knowledge]] encyclopedia written by Zheng Qiao (鄭樵) in the [[Song dynasty]], containing 200 chapters on diverse topics.
==Contents== After the ''[[Tongdian]]'', it was the second encyclopedia of the ''Santong'' (The Three Encyclopedias), which were often published together. It is also included second among the ''Shitong'' (The Ten Encyclopedias), compiled in the Qing dynasty.<ref>Wilkinson, Endymion Porter. ''Chinese History: A Manual''. Harvard University Asia Center, 1998. Page 524.</ref> The ''Tongzhi'' became a model for most of the later encyclopedias.
''Tongzhi'' is arranged in 200 volumes (''juan''), plus three volumes of notes. The historical information covers from earliest times to the end of the [[Tang dynasty]]. The contents include basic annals, yearly chronicles, hereditary houses, ranked biographies, and twenty monographs (''lüe'' 略) on various topics, the last of which are considered the most original part.<ref name="E526">Endymion, 526.</ref> The twenty monographs, which comprise 52 volumes, deal with clans, the [[Chinese character classification|six classes of characters]], phonetics, astronomy, geography, capital cities, rituals, posthumous names, vessels and robes, music, official titles, the examination system, punishment, food and money, arts and literature, collation, images, metal and stone, disasters and fortunes, insects and plants. The comprehensivity of these monographs has long been noted; the ''[[Siku Quanshu Zongmu Tiyao]]'' (completed in 1798) praised them in particular.
The chapter on images (''Tu pu lüe'' 图谱略) has attracted considerable interest among art theorists. In this section, he gives images primacy in transmitting values, using metaphor that compares the images as the warp (''jing'' 經) and the text as the weft (''wei'' 緯).<ref>Han Si. ''A Chinese Word on Image: Zheng Qiao (1104-1162) and His Thought on Images''. Acta Universitatis Gothoburgensis, 2008.</ref>
The chapter on arts and literature (''Yi wen lüe'' 藝文略) has the most detailed bibliographic scheme in pre-modern China.<ref name="E526"/>
==Modern editions== * Shanghai guji, 1993 * Zhonghua, 1995
==Notes== {{Wikisourcelang|zh|通志|Tongzhi}} {{reflist}}
